ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, Lytoceras fimbriatum, collected from the Margaritatus Zone, Middle Lias of Early Jurassic, Late Pliensbachian age from Lyme Regis, Dorset (SW England).
NarNarrative: Lytoceras fimbricatum was an ammonite that lived in the Jurassic seas. It was alive at the same time as the dinosaurs, and was preyed upon (eaten) by large marine reptiles like pliosaurs that also lived in the sea. Ammonites are now extinct (they died out at the same time as the dinosaurs, 65 million years ago), and were similar to the modern pearly nautilus that lives in the warm waters of the Pacific Ocean.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Dorset (SW England), Lyme Regis

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, Dactylioceras commune, collected from the Commune Sub-zone, Upper Lias of Early Jurassic age. Collected by Emma Smith.
NarNarrative: Dactylioceras commune has evenly spaced ribs (ridges) covering the surface of its shell. Ammonites were sea creatures that looked a bit like the modern nautilus that lives in the Pacific Ocean. They probably ate plankton (tiny plants), and small sea animals, including young brachiopods (lamp shells), corals and bryozoans. This ammonite probably comes from rocks in North Yorkshire. It is a very common in the Whitby area.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: no locality data

SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: no locality data

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil brittle star, Ophioderma egertoni Broderip, collected from the Middle Lias, Starfish Bed (?) of Early Jurassic age from Dorset (SW England). Collected by J. Goring.
NarNarrative: There are two fossilised brittle-stars on this piece of rock. Brittle-stars are a type of star fish that have very thin arms. Their arms are very brittle and they break very easily. Fortunately, if they lose an arm, they can grow a new one. Brittle stars are still alive today. They move around by jerking their arms forward in pairs.
LocalSum: UK, England, Dorset (SW England)

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, Euhoplites lautus, collected from the Lautus Zone, Gault Clay (?), Speeton Clay (?) of Early Cretaceous, Middle Albian age.
NarNarrative: Ammonites are extinct sea creatures that looked like octopuses, but lived in a coiled shell. The shell kept the animal floating under the water and gave it some protection. Ammonites were able to swim using jet propulsion (squirting water), and fed on fish and shrimps that they caught in their tentacles. This ammonite shell has ridges and grooves running around the outside, and stout widely spaced ribs. The species, Euhoplites lautus was around for about 1 to 2 million years. Its presence in the rocks is used to identify a particular time zone (lautus zone) in the Cretaceous period.

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil crinoid (Sea Lily), Woodocrinus macrodactylus Koninck, collected from the Millstone Grit Group, Main Limestone (?) of Early Carboniferous, Namurian, Pendleian age from Swaledale, North Yorkshire (NE England). Collected by Joseph Duff.
NarNarrative: This specimen shows the skeletons of three crinoids in a colony known as a garden. Each skeleton has a stem that attached the animal to the sea floor, a calyx (cup) that contained the fleshy body and tentacle-like arms that were used to collect food. All the parts are made up of separate plates known as ossicles which also make up much of the limestone host rock. Crinoids lived in warm tropical seas in varying water depths. Crinoids (sea lilies) are actually animals related to star fish.
LocalSum: UK, England, North Yorkshire (NE England), Swaledale

ColPhysicalDescription: Shale bearing impression of ornamented dermal bone.

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod (snail), Buccinum sp., collected from the Red Crag of Quaternary, Early Pleistocene age. Collected by William K. Loftus. With encrusting serpulid.
NarNarrative: The thick shell of Buccinum shows that it lived in a high-energy (rough water) environment. It was found in rocks deposited in water up to 15m deep. It moved around on the sea floor and had a short siphon (tube) that it kept above the mud to maintain a flow of clean water into its body. Buccinum was a predator that fed on bivalves by drilling holes through their shells to reach their soft bodies.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: no locality data

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil coral, Syringopora ramulosa Goldfuss, collected from the Carboniferous Limestone (?) of Early Carboniferous, Dinantian, Visean age from Otterburn, Northumberland (NE England). Collected by William K. Loftus.
NarNarrative: This mass of slender tube-shaped corallites (coral skeletons) is part of the colonial coral Syringopora. The corallites are joined together at regular intervals by smaller connecting tubes that strengthen the colony. A living coral polyp, similar to a sea anemone, occupied a cup shaped hollow at the top of each tube. Like most corals it lived on the floor of warm shallow seas near the equator.
LocalSum: UK, England, Northumberland (NE England), Otterburn

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil coral, Michelinia megastoma, collected from the Great Scar Limestone Group (?) of Early (?) Carboniferous, Dinantian (?), Visean (?) age from Grange, Lancashire (NW England). Collected by J. Goring.
NarNarrative: The small colonial (living as a group) coral Michelinia has unusually large six-sided corallites (individual coral skeletons). A living coral polyp occupied the cup shaped hollow at the top of each tube. The polyp was similar to a sea anemone with a mouth in the centre of a ring of tentacles, which it used to capture small animals as food. Like most corals it lived attached to the floor of warm shallow seas near the equator.
LocalSum: UK, England, Lancashire (NW England), Grange

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil mammal (Mammoth), Mammuthus primigenius, collected from unspecified rocks of Quaternary, Pleistocene age from Worms near Pfalz, Germany. Juvenile lower jaw with two milk molars.
NarNarrative: Woolly mammoths became extinct about 10 000 years ago and are symbolic of the Ice Ages in the Quaternary period. They are well known from Stone Age (Palaeolithic) cave paintings, especially in France, and the discovery of complete bodies in frozen ground in Siberia. They had long, black hair and a hump of fat behind the head, used as a food source (like camels). This lower jaw bone with two milk molars is from a juvenile (young) mammoth. The distinctive ridges on the teeth are typical of mammoths and were used to grind down the tough plants that they fed on.
SciName: Mammuthus primigenius : Elephantidae : Proboscidea : Mammalia : Chordata
LocalSum: Europe, Germany, Pfalz (nr.), Worms

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil coral, Alveolana semiovata, collected from the Red Crag of Quaternary, Early Pleistocene age from Suffolk (SE England).
NarNarrative: This round fossil is a colonial coral and is made up of many individual corallites that have fused together to form a framework of angular tubes. A close look at the tubes shows the small holes where the soft-bodied coral polyps lived. The coral polyp fed by catching food particles out of the sea water with its tentacles. Alveolaria lived in warm water which was dominated by bivalves and gastropods at about 10 - 15 metre depths.
LocalSum: UK, England, Suffolk (SE England)

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil trilobite, Paladin mucronatus, collected from the Middle Limestone Group of Early Carboniferous, Brigantian age from Cullernose Point (nr.), Howick Bay, Northumberland (NE England). Collected by Emma Smith.
NarNarrative: This small trilobite belongs to the only group of trilobites, the Proetida, which survived into the Carboniferous period. After this time trilobites became extinct. They look similar to wood-lice today, but they lived on the floor of warm, shallow, tropical seas where they scavenged for food. In order to grow, trilobites, like all arthropods (such as crabs and lobsters), had to moult their hard external skeletons, so one trilobite could produce several different sized fossils during its life.
ComName_tab: , paladin mucronatus, Animalia Invertebrata Arthropoda Trilobita
LocalSum: UK, England, Northumberland (NE England), Howick Bay, Cullernose Point (nr.)

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Sanguinolites variabilis, collected from the Scremerston Coal Group, Redesdale Ironstone of Early Carboniferous, Dinantian, Visean, Asbian age from Comb (?), Northumberland (NE England). Collected by John Dunn.
NarNarrative: This bivalve burrowed into the surface of shallow tropical sea floor. It fed on small food particles that it filtered out of the sea water. The bivalve probably died in its burrow because its two shells have remained joined together. Sanguinolites is usually found in a specialised high density - low diversity fauna that could tolerate extremely salty (hypersaline) sea water such as that found in coastal lagoons. It is often found with another bivalve Modiolus after which this specialised community is named.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Northumberland (NE England), Redesdale, Comb (?)

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil cephalopod, Actinoceras breyrii, collected from the Comb Limestone, Pipers Cross Limestone (?), Scremerston Coal Group of Early Carboniferous, Dinantian, Visean, Asbian age from Comb, Northumberland (NE England). Collected by John Dunn.
NarNarrative: Orthocones were animals that looked similar to squid. They had a bulbous tube (siphuncle) that linked the individual chambers in the cone-shaped shell. The actual animal lived in the largest last chamber of the shell and the smaller chambers were filled with gas. This made Actinoceras buoyant. It swam using jet propulsion, forcing water out of its body. It was a carnivores and fed mainly on shrimps, crabs and fish caught in its tentacles. Some orthocones grew to enormous sizes.
GeoRock: Scremerston Coal Group & Comb Limestone & Pipers Cross Limestone (?)
ComName_tab: , actinoceras breyerii, Animalia Invertebrata Mollusca Cephalopoda Nautiloidea
LocalSum: UK, England, Northumberland (NE England), Redesdale, Comb

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod, Soleniscus rectilinea, collected from the Comb Limestone, Pipers Cross Limestone (?), Scremerston Coal Group of Early Carboniferous, Dinantian, Visean, Asbian age from Comb, Northumberland (NE England). Collected by John Dunn.
NarNarrative: The thin shell of this gastropod (sea snail) suggests that it lived in a low-energy (clam water) environment where it was unlikely to suffer any physical damage. Soleniscus lived on the surface of the sea floor and was probably a scavenger that fed on dead animals and plants. It was part of a shallow water community that lived in a warm tropical sea.
GeoRock: Scremerston Coal Group & Comb Limestone & Pipers Cross Limestone (?)
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Northumberland (NE England), Redesdale, Comb

NarNarrative: The shell of this sea snail has been dissolved away to leave a cast of the smooth interior. It appears that the original shell was thin suggesting that the snail lived in a low-energy (calm water) environment where it was unlikely to suffer any physical damage. It was part of a shallow water community that lived on the floor of a warm tropical sea.
GeoRock: Scremerston Coal Group & Comb Limestone & Pipers Cross Limestone (?)

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil goniatite, Glyphioceras truncatum, collected from the Redesdale Ironstone, Scremerston Coal Group of Early Carboniferous, Dinantian, Visean, Asbian age from Northumberland (NE England). Collected by John Dunn.
NarNarrative: GlyphiocerasGonatites were similar to the coiled-shelled ammonites but more primitive. This specimen shows the septa (walls) that divide up the inside of the shell. The animal was similar to a squid and lived in the outermost chamber and the smaller chambers were filled with gas so that the shell was buoyant. Glyphioceras lived near the surface of the sea and swam using jet propulsion, forcing water out of its body. It was carnivorous feeding on small animals caught in its tentacles.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Northumberland (NE England)

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod, Euomphalus cirrus, collected from the Comb Limestone, Pipers Cross Limestone (?), Scremerston Coal Group of Early Carboniferous, Dinantian, Visean, Asbian age from Comb (?), Northumberland (NE England). Collected by John Dunn.
NarNarrative: The shell of this sea snail has been dissolved away to leave a cast of the smooth inside. The shell had a slit in the upper surface where a siphon (tube) pumped out water after the snail had extracted oxygen from it. The shell was thick and heavily built suggesting that the snail lived in a high-energy (rough water) shoreline environment. Euomphalus fed on food particles that it collected out of the sea water.
GeoRock: Scremerston Coal Group & Comb Limestone & Pipers Cross Limestone (?)
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Northumberland (NE England), Redesdale, Comb

NarNarrative: The coiled shell of this fossil has been dissolved away revealing the internal septa (walls) and chambers. The animal was similar to a squid and lived in the outermost chamber of the shell and the smaller chambers were filled with gas that made Vestinautilus buoyant. Nautiloids lived near the surface of the sea and swam using jet propulsion, forcing water out of their bodies. They were carnivores and fed mainly on shrimps, crabs and fish they caught in their tentacles.

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, 'Ammonites' konigi, collected from the Kellaways Rock of Late Jurassic, Callovian age from Morpeth (?), Wiltshire (SW England). Collected by I.G. Lowe. Originally three specimens, two found.
NarNarrative: An ammonite from Jurassic rocks approximately 160 million years old. Ammonites looked similar to the modern Nautilus that lives in the Pacific Ocean. They had tentacles and a coiled shell, and used a jet propulsion system, which enabled them to move backwards very quickly, by squirting water from their shell. Ammonites died out 65 million years ago, the same time as the dinosaurs.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, Oppelia fallax, collected from unspecified rocks of Middle Jurassic, rocks of Late Bajocian or Early Bathonian age from Oxfordshire (SE England).
NarNarrative: The surface of this ammonite is covered with frilly lines, known as suture lines. These lines are formed where the septa (walls inside the shell that divide it into separate chambers), join the side of the shell. The suture lines are the same shape as the edges of the septa, which are frilled. Different ammonites have differently shaped suture lines.

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil fish , Sparnodus macrophthalmus, collected from the 'Fish Beds' of Tertiary, Middle Eocene, Lutetian - Bartonian age from Monte Bolca, Verona, Italy. Collected by N.C. Cookson.
NarNarrative: This tropical fossil fish was collected from one of Europe's earliest and most famous fossil localities, Monte Bolca, 30 km northwest of Verona in the Italian Alps. The fossil fish found there convinced 16th century naturalists that fossils were actually the remains of living organisms. The fish are preserved in a rock deposited on a seabed where there was no oxygen. This stopped bacteria growing and causing decay. The fossils are therefore very well preserved. This fossil is named after it's large eyes (macro meaning large, and opthalmus meaning eyes).
ComName_tab: sparnodus & macrophthalmus, Animalia & Chordata & Vertebrata & Pisces
LocalSum: Italy, Verona, Monte Bolca

NarNarrative:
Shells

,

Shells are made of hard material to protect animals like armour. This keeps them safe from a predator's claws, beak or teeth. Some animals always have shells attached to their body. Other animals discard their shells and grow new ones as they age. Have you ever found a sea shell on the beach? That shell used to belong to an animal

,

Hawksbill Turtle

,
ComName_tab: , calymene sp., Animalia Invertebrata Arthropoda Trilobita

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil brachiopod, Lingula mytiloides, collected from the Scremerston Coal Group, Redesdale Shale of Early Carboniferous, Dinantian, Visean, Asbian age from Comb Quarry, Redesdale, Northumberland (NE England). Collected by John Dunn.
NarNarrative: Lingula is an unusual and very successful brachiopod (lamp shell). It lives in a burrow where it moves up and down on a long fleshy stalk called a pedicle. Its shells are held together only by soft tissues. Lingula was one of the first brachiopods to appear in the fossil record in the Cambrian period and can be found all over the world today. It lives in inshore brackish (slightly salty) water and tidal areas where it filters tiny food particles out of the water.
ComName_tab: Lamp Shell, lingula mytilloides, Animalia Invertebrata Brachiopoda
LocalSum: UK, England, Northumberland (NE England), Redesdale, Comb

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil crinoid (Sea Lily), Poteriocrinus crassus, collected from the Carboniferous Limestone of Carboniferous, Visean, Brigantian or Namurian (?) age from Roscobie, Fife, Scotland. Collected by James Walter Kirkby. Stem.
NarNarrative: This specimen shows parts of a crinoid stem that was used to attach the animal to the sea floor and is made up of many separate plates or ossicles. The scars on the stem mark the position where simple branches known as cirri were attached when the crinoid was alive. Crinoids lived in warm tropical seas in varying water depths. They often formed large colonies known as gardens and were an important component of reef communities. Crinoids (sea lilies) are actually animals related to star fish.
GeoAge: Carboniferous & Visean & Brigantian or Namurian (?) / 315 - 330 my (?)
LocalSum: UK, Scotland, Fife (Scotland), Dunfermiline (nr.), Roscobie

NarNarrative: Sagenodus is a type of lung-fish that had an eel-like body and grew up to 30 cm in length. Lungfish were the first vertebrates (animals with backbones) adapted to breath air. They lived in shallow, salt and fresh water that was liable to become stagnant and dry up. The tooth plate formed part of a jaw palate that was used to crush the mollusc shells and crustaceans that the fish ate.

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil fish (tooth), Strepsodus sauroides Huxley, collected from the Modiolaris Zone, Middle Coal Measures, Low Main Seam of Late Carboniferous, Westphalian, Duckmantian age from Newsham Colliery, Blyth, Northumberland (NE England).
NarNarrative: This tooth is from an early bony fish that grew to a length of about 3 metres. It belonged to a group of fishes with lobe-shaped fins that also included the coelacanths. Scales, teeth and vertebrae are all that is usually found of the fish. They lived in freshwater lakes and rivers and were probably predators that fed mainly on smaller fish.
GeoRock: Coal Measures Formation (Middle) & Low Main Seam

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil crustacean, Waterstonella grantonensis Schram, collected from the Granton Shrimp Bed, Gullane Formation, Strathclyde Group of Early Carboniferous, Dinantian, Visean, Asbian age from Granton Harbour (promenade foreshore near), Leith (docks), Scotland.
NarNarrative: This fossil specimen shows several complete and many fragments of primitive shrimps. The white soft shells (carapaces) are made out of chitin, a material similar to finger nails. Various parts of their bodies can be identified including heads, thoraxes (upper bodies), legs and forked tails. These shrimps lived in salt or brackish (slightly salty) water lagoons and were scavengers that fed on organic debris found on the bed of the lagoon.
GeoRock: Strathclyde Group & Gullane Formation & Granton Shrimp Bed
ComName_tab: , waterstonella grantonensis (schram), Animalia Invertebrata Arthropoda Crustacea
LocalSum: UK, Scotland, Lothian (Scotland), Leith (docks), Granton Harbour

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil plant (club moss), Lepidodendron sp., collected from the Coal Measures of Late Carboniferous, Westphalian B age. Collected by Rev G.C. Abbs. Section of trunk showing leaf-scars.
NarNarrative: Lepidodendron is a large, tree-like club moss, that grew in the Carboniferous coal measure forests 300 million years ago. These plants grew up to 40 metres in height, and had a crown of branches right at the top, with cones at the ends of the branches. Lepidodendron has a very distinctive diamond-shaped pattern covering the branches and the upper part of the trunk. This is formed from leaf scars, where the leaves have fallen off.

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil trilobite, Acidaspis brightii, collected from the Coalbrookdale Formation of Early Silurian, Wenlock, Sheinwoodian - Homerian age from Wren's Nest (?), Dudley, West Midlands (Midland England). Collected by Ald. T.P. Barkas.
NarNarrative: The quarries and mines at Wren's Nest, Dudley, have long been famous for the superbly preserved fossils contained in the Silurian limestone rocks. Amongst the most spectacular of these are the trilobites. They look a bit like overgrown woodlice but are more closely related to crabs and lobsters. This complete specimen shows the head (cephalon), body (thorax), and small spiny tail (pygidium). Acidaspis probably crawled about on the Silurian seabed, scavenging for food.
GeoAge: Silurian & Wenlock & shelf einwoodian - Homerian / 423 - 428 my
ComName_tab: , acidaspis brightii (murchison), Animalia Invertebrata Arthropoda Trilobita
LocalSum: UK, England, West Midlands (Midland England), Dudley, Wren's Nest

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil fish , Lepidotus sp., collected from the Lias of Early Jurassic age.
NarNarrative: This fossil is part of the body of the Jurassic fish Lepidotus. Incomplete fossils like this one are much more common than complete fossils. When an animal dies, and starts to decay, it needs to be buried quickly in order to stay together. Palaeontologists (people who study fossils), have to look for clues, to decide what sort of animal (or plant), a fossil is from. The shiny black diamond-shaped pieces covering the surface of this fossil are fish scales. It is quite easy to identify fish scales when there are several of them like this, because they form a clear pattern.
ComName_tab: lepidotus & sp. (agassiz), Animalia & Chordata & Vertebrata & Pisces
LocalSum: no locality data

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil fish , Mesodon bucklandi, collected from the Coral Rag of Middle Jurassic, Bathonian age from Weymouth (north shore), Dorset (SW England).
NarNarrative: The smooth rounded pebble-like parts of this fossil are the teeth of the now-extinct fish Mesodon bucklandi. Rounded teeth like these ones would be used for chewing and crushing food. Their shape is very different from the sharp, pointed teeth that other types of fish use to hold and tear their food.
ComName_tab: mesodon & bucklandi, Animalia & Chordata & Vertebrata & Pisces
LocalSum: UK, England, Dorset (SW England), Weymouth (north shore)

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil fish, Osteolepis macrolepidotus Agassiz, collected from unspecified rocks of Middle Devonian age from Orkney (Scotland). Collected by David M. Lumsden.
NarNarrative: Osteolepis macrolepidotus was a large fish with a powerful tail, and was probably a scavenger, feeding on whatever was available. It would have lived in a large, fresh water lake, which was probably not very rich in oxygen, especially the deeper water. These conditions were not ideal for the animals living in the lake, but would have been ideal for the preservation and fossilisation of the fish once they were dead.
LocalSum: UK, Scotland, Orkney (Scotland)

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil trace fossil, unidentified, collected from the Loweswater Formation, Skiddaw Group of Early Ordovician, Arenig, Moridunian age from Barf, Bassenthwaite, Cumbria (NW England). Collected by John Jeffrey. 'Worm tracks' and plant remains.
NarNarrative: Trace fossils are the fossilised remains of an animal activity. In this fossil, some animals have made burrows in the mud of the seabed whilst looking for food. These burrows have become fossilised as the mud changed to a mudstone. We do not know what animal made these burrows.
LocalSum: UK, England, Cumbria (NW England), Bassenthwaite, Barf

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil fish , Knightia alta, collected from the Green River Formation of Tertiary, Early - Middle Eocene, Ypresian - Lutetian age from Colorado, USA. Collected by David M. Lumsden.
NarNarrative: This freshwater fossil fish comes from Green River in the USA, one of the worlds 'super fossil sites'. It is the state fossil of Wyoming and was named after the first state geologist, Wilbur Clinton Knight. Knightia is a relative of the present day herring, and grew to a length of 10 to 25 cm. They lived in large shoals. The fish population died out very suddenly and large numbers were preserved as fossils in the fine-grained lake sediments.
ComName_tab: Shark, palaeoniscid, Animalia & Chordata & Vertebrata & Pisces
LocalSum: North America, USA, Colorado

ColPhysicalDescription: Plaster cast of a fossil reptile (pterodactyl), Scaphognathus sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Late Jurassic age from Germany.
NarNarrative: This is a plaster cast of a pterosaur skeleton. Pterosaurs were not dinosaurs, although they were alive at the same time. They were a group of flying reptiles that had a large flap of skin between the body and one very long finger bone to form a wing. They are often called Pterodactyls (which means 'winged finger'). They did not have feathers like birds. Pterosaurs had thin bones, many of which were hollow, giving them light skeletons. They are very important animals as they give us information about how vertebrates (animals with backbones) took to the air using true powered flight (and not just gliding).
LocalSum: Europe, Germany

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil fish, Palaeoniscum freieslebeni, collected from the Marl Slate of Late Permian, Zechstein (Durham Province), EZ1 age from Houghton-le-Spring, Co Durham (NE England). Collected by Robinson.
NarNarrative: Palaeoniscum was a small herring-like fish that probably swam in shoals (groups of fish). 250 million years ago, when this fish was alive, the sea was much warmer than it is now, because Sunderland (near where this fossil came from), was much closer to the equator than it is today. This is because continental drift (the movement of the plates that cover the surface of the earth), causes the shape and postion of the continents to slowly change.
ComName_tab: palaeoniscum & freieslebeni (de blainville), Actinopterygii & Palaeonisciformes (After Romer)
LocalSum: UK, England, Co. Durham (NE England), Houghton-le-Spring

GeoRock: Concretionary Limestone Formation & Magnesian Limestone (lower bed)
LocalSum: UK, England, Tyne and Wear (NE England), Sunderland, Fulwell Hill (north side)

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil brachiopod (Lamp Shell), Pterospirifer alatus, collected from the Ford Formation (reef facies) of Late Permian, Zechstein (Durham Province), EZ1 age from Humbledon Hill, Sunderland, Tyne and Wear (NE England).
NarNarrative: Pterospirifer alatus is a brachiopod (lamp shell). This fossil is from the reef (a ridge teeming with life, close to the coast), that existed in the Sunderland area 250 million years ago. It would have lived on the surface of the reef, allowing the nutrient-rich sea water to enter its open shells, from which it would extract the food that it needed.
ComName_tab: Lamp Shell, pterospirifer alatus (schlotheim), Brachiopod Articulata
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Brachiopoda & Articulata : : : Articulata : Brachiopoda
LocalSum: UK, England, Tyne and Wear (NE England), Sunderland

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil brachiopod (Lamp Shell), Spiriferellina cristata, collected from the Ford Formation (reef facies) of Late Permian, Zechstein (Durham Province), EZ1 age from Humbledon Hill, Sunderland, Tyne and Wear (NE England). Collected by James Walter Kirkby.
NarNarrative: This brachiopod (lamp shell) has a very small shell. This is because the Zechstein Sea, where these shellfish lived 250 million years ago, was very salty, which made life difficult for some of the animals that lived in it. This brachiopod lived on a reef, a community teeming with life, on a ridge close to and parallel to the coast. It used a pedicle, a long thin muscle that came out of a tiny hole at the top of the shell, to fix itself to the surface of the reef. These creatures often lived in groups, known as 'nests'.
ComName_tab: Lamp Shell, spiriferellina cristata (schlotheim), Brachiopod Articulata
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Brachiopoda & Articulata : : : Articulata : Brachiopoda
LocalSum: UK, England, Tyne and Wear (NE England), Sunderland, Humbledon Hill Quarry

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimens of fossil brachiopods (lamp shells) including Stenoscisma schlotheimi and Orbiculoidea konincki and bryozoan Fenestella retiformis, collected from the Raisby Formation of Late Permian, Zechstein (Durham Province), EZ1 age from East Thickley, Shildon, Co Durham (NE England). Collected by Reed.
NarNarrative: Stenoscisma schlotheimi is a brachiopod (lamp shell), that lived on a reef off the coast in the Zechstein sea 250 million years ago. It attached itself to the sea floor with a pedicle, a thin muscle that came out through a small hole in the top of its shell. Orbiculoidea konincki (the round white shell) is an inarticulate brachiopod, meaning that its two shells are held together only by muscles (most brachiopods have a hinge at the top of the shells, which helps to keep the shells together).
ComName_tab: Lamp Shell, stenoscisma schlotheimi (von buch), Brachiopod Articulata, Lamp Shell, stenoscisma schlotheimi (von buch), Brachiopod Articulata
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Brachiopoda & Articulata : : : Articulata : Brachiopoda, Animalia & Invertebrata & Brachiopoda & Articulata : : : Articulata : Brachiopoda
LocalSum: UK, England, Co. Durham (NE England), West Shildon

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil tooth, unidentified, collected from the Great Oolite of Middle Jurassic, Bathonian age from Minchinhampton, Gloucestershire (SW England).
NarNarrative: This tooth has been fossilised in a piece of oolitic limestone. We don't know what kind of animal this tooth belonged to. The tooth is long and curved, and has ridges that run along its length. The smooth, shiny end is the part of the tooth that would have been attached to the jaw bone of the animal. Oolitic limestone is a rock that contains a lot of small round grains, which you may be able to see if you look closely. It is formed in the sea near the shore.
LocalSum: UK, England, Gloucestershire (SW England), Cotswolds, Minchinhampton (?)

NarNarrative: This fossil has the common name of 'Honeycomb Coral' because its skeleton looks like the honeycomb made by bees. Although this coral is very common in the Silurian rocks exposed at Dudley, it is named 'Gothlandicus' after the island of Gothland in the Baltic where it was first discovered.

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Trigonia sp., collected from the Lower (?) Oolite, Inferior Oolite (?) of Middle (?) Jurassic age. Collected by F. Schnitger, 1886.
NarNarrative: The name of this bivalve describes its triangular shape. The shell is covered with strong ribs which gave the shell extra strength. It may have lived in a high energy (rough water) environment. Trigonia burrowed in the surface of coarse sand in coastal areas including the intertidal zone (the area between high and low tide). It was a filter feeder, capturing small food particles out of the seawater. Trigonia was ery common in the Jurassic period (about 170 million years ago). Living relatives are found today but only around the coast of Australia.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve (rudistid), Hippurites sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Late Cretaceous age. Collected by J. Hancock, 1889.
NarNarrative: Rudists are an extinct group of bivalves (meaning two shells or valves) that lived in warm tropical seas. They had tube-shaped shells that were attached to the sea floor and grew like corals. The large tube shell contains lots of flat plates in the lower part and a small space in the upper part where the animal lived. The upper shell was held in place with soft flesh and fitted like a lid on the top of the tube.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca
LocalSum: no locality data

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Trigonia sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Cretaceous age from France.
NarNarrative: The name of this bivalve describes its triangular shape. Its shell is covered with angular ridges and hollows that made it strong. Trigonia burrowed in the surface of coarse shelly sand in areas near the coast, including the intertidal zone (the area between high and low tide). It was a filter feeder that extracted food particles out of the sea water. Trigonia lived all over the world in the Cretaceous period. Living relatives are found today but only around the coast of Australia.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca
LocalSum: Europe, France

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil echinoid (sea urchin), Cidaris florigemma, collected from the Coral Rag of Late Jurassic, Oxfordian age.
NarNarrative: Cidaris (which means 'tiara' or 'diadem' in Persian) florigemma was a sea urchin. It had a test (the hard, outer shell) that was shaped a bit like a jam donuht, with wart like bumps in between wavy lines of tiny holes. Modern Cidaris sea urchins live in warm seas. They walk across the sea floor using their large strong spines like stilts.
LocalSum: no locality data

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod, Hippochrenes sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary, Eocene (?) age.
NarNarrative: This sea snail has an unusual flat lip fused around the opening in its shell. The function of the lip is unclear although it probably supported the gastropod on soft clay seabeds. Hippochrenes was part of a rich warm subtropical shallow water community. The thin shell and clay that it was found in suggest a low-energy (calm) environment. It was a predator and a scavenger that fed on live molluscs, dead animals and plants on the sea floor.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: no locality data

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod, Sycostoma bulbiformis, collected from the Cornatum Zone = Intricatum Zone of Tertiary, Middle Eocene, Lutetian age from Damery, France.
NarNarrative: This smooth sea snails name is taken from its bulbous (bulb-shaped) form. Growth lines are present on the outside of the shell. Sycostoma was part of a rich warm subtropical shallow water community. The thin shell suggests that it lived in a sheltered, low-energy habitat where the water was quite calm. It was a predator and a scavenger that fed on live molluscs, dead animals and plants as it moved around on the sea floor.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: Europe, France, Damery

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Pecten sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary, Miocene age from Piedmont, Italy.
NarNarrative: This round scallop has a lightweight shell with radiating ribs that give the shell strength, and prominent 'wings' next to the hinge line (the area where the two shells (valves) meet). Pecten lived freely on the surface of the sea bed where it fed on tiny food particles that it filtered out of the water. It could also swim by 'clapping' its shells together but usually only did so to escape from predators such as fish. After the scallop died its two shells came apart and were preserved separately.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca
LocalSum: Europe, Italy, Piedmont

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil crustacean (lobster), Meyeria sp., collected from the Forbesi Zone = Fissicostatus Zone, Atherfield Clay Formation of Early Cretaceous, Early Aptian age from Atherfield, Isle of Wight, Hampshire (SE England). Collected by David M. Lumsden.
NarNarrative: The head, thoracic (chest) segments and tail of Meyeria have been well preserved in a clay nodule that formed around its body as the soft parts decayed. Like living relatives, the prawn was a free swimming animal that fed on food particles that it collected from sea water. The number of fossils discovered and the lobster-like appearance of Meyeria, has resulted in the layer of rocks that it is found in being called the Lobster Beds.
ComName_tab: Lobster, meyeria sp., Animalia Invertebrata Arthropoda Crustacea
LocalSum: UK, England, Hampshire (SE England), Isle of Wight, Atherfield

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bryozoan (sea mat or moss animal), Synocladia virgulacea, collected from the Ford Formation (reef facies) of Late Permian age.
NarNarrative: Synocladia virgulacea is a bryozoan or moss animal. Funnel shaped bryozoan colonies looked a bit like some modern corals. The tiny individual moss animals (known as zooids) that lived in little holes in these structures looked a bit like tiny sea anemones. They used their tentacles to help catch the tiny plants and animals that they ate.
ComName_tab: Sea Mat (or Moss Animal), synocladia virgulacea (phillips), Animalia Invertebrata Bryozoa
LocalSum: no locality data

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Glycymeris brevirostris, collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary (?), Early (?) Eocene age.
NarNarrative: This shellfish lived in a vertical position in a shallow burrow on a sandy sea bed and fed on tiny food particles that it filtered out of the sea water. This group of fossils contains many single shells, which suggests that they were washed together by sea currents after they died. This is because each shellfish had two shells joined together when they were alive which broke apart when they died. Glycymeris lived near the coast and were often washed out of their burrows during storms.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca
LocalSum: no locality data

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve (oyster), Ostrea sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary (?) age.
NarNarrative: Fossil oysters had thick shells that protected their soft bodies in high-energy (rough water) coastal environments. The ribs are present only on the concave shell that was fixed to the sea floor; the other shell was smaller, flat and opened like a lid. They formed large colonies along coasts and are often used to identify ancient shorelines. They fed on tiny food particles that they filtered out of the water. The holes in the shell were bored by worms.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca
LocalSum: no locality data

SciName: Animalia & Chordata & Vertebrata & Mammalia : : : Mammalia : Chordata

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Pecten sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary (?) age.
NarNarrative: The slightly convex thin scallop shell has prominent wings and is covered with radiating ribs that strengthen it. Pecten lived freely on the seabed and fed on tiny food particles that it filtered out of the water. It could also swim by 'clapping' its two shells together but usually only did so to escape from predators. The hole in the shell was made by a predatory gastropod so that it could feed on scallop's soft body.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca
LocalSum: no locality data

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod, Athleta spinosus, collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary, Eocene age from Paris Basin, France.
NarNarrative: The thick sea snail shell is covered with spiral ridges and vertical ribs. Athleta lived in warm subtropical shallow coastal waters in a community dominated by gastropods and bivalves. It was a predator and a scavenger that fed on live molluscs, dead animals and plants on the sea floor. The snail shell was one of the first British fossils to be given a scientific name using the new Linnean classification system by Daniel Solander in 1766.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: Europe, France, Paris, Paris Basin

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod, Globularia sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary, Eocene age from Paris Basin, France.
NarNarrative: The globe shaped shell gives this sea snail its classified name. The soft body of the snail filled the last coil of the shell with the round opening. Globularia was a predator that fed on bivalves that lived buried in the surface of the sea floor. It was part of a rich and varied bivalve-gastropod fauna shallow that lived in a warm shallow subtropical sea.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: Europe, France, Paris, Paris Basin

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod (snail), Turritella sulcifera, collected from the Bracklesham Group of Tertiary, Early - Middle Eocene, Late Ypresian - Lutetian age from Bracklesham, Sussex (SE England).
NarNarrative: This sea snail is named from its slender cone-shaped or 'turreted' shell. The shell lay flat or inclined gently downwards so that the snails body was level with the sea floor where its food supply was most abundant. It fed on micro-organisms and other tiny food particles that it filtered out of the sea water. It was part of a rich and varied gastropod-bivalve fauna found on the floor of a warm shallow subtropical sea.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Sussex (SE England), Bracklesham

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil plant, collected from the Abbreviatum Zone = Intricatum Zone, Bracklesham Group, Bagshot Formation of Tertiary, Eocene age from Alum Bay, Isle of Wight, Hampshire (SE England).
NarNarrative: This single willow-like leaf has been preserved as an impression in grey clay. These particular also often have fossils of the leaves of fig trees, laurels, fan palms, aralias and other subtropical plants. The clays were deposited (laid down) either in fresh water lagoons or an estuary along the coast of a warm shallow sea.
LocalSum: UK, England, Hampshire (SE England), Isle of Wight, Alum Bay

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod (snail), Neritina conoidea, collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary, Eocene age from Paris Basin, France.
NarNarrative: The round body chamber of this sea snail encloses the early coils of its shell. The slit-like opening in the shell had a siphon (tube) at each end, which the snail used to pump water into and away from its body. The snail fed on tiny food particles that it filtered out of the water. Neritina lived in warm water on the floor of a large lake basin that was flooded by the sea from time to time.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: Europe, France, Paris, Paris Basin

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod (snail), Cerithium serratum, collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary, Eocene age from Paris Basin, France.
NarNarrative: This sea snail has a slender cone-shaped shell with many angular coils covered in spiny nodes. Cerithium lived on the muddy floor of a large lake basin that was flooded by the sea from time to time as sea levels varied. It was part of the rich gastropod-bivalve fauna that lived in the warm subtropical waters. The snail probably lived with its shell partially buried and fed on tiny food particles that it filtered out of the water.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: Europe, France, Paris Basin

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Glycymeris glycymeris, collected from the Red Crag of Quaternary, Early Pleistocene age from Walton-on-the-Naze, Essex (SE England). Collected by William K. Loftus.
NarNarrative: The outside of this round single bivalve shell has fine radiating ribs (ridges) that are cut by the growth lines (lines created as the shell grew larger). The unusual marks on the shell are borings that were made by sea-living worms. Glycymeris lived in a vertical position in a shallow burrow on sandy seabeds. It fed on tiny food particles that it filtered out of sea water. When the animal died the two valves usually separated.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Essex (SE England), Felixtowe (nr.), Walton on the Naze

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil nest (bird), Ducks nest with eggs, collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary (?) age.
NarNarrative: This is a nest containing the eggs of a duck. It is not a true fossil as the nest and eggs have only been covered in a layer of limestone (calcium carbonate). This calcium carbonate came from water which must have been flowing or dripping onto the nest. This is probably why the duck abandoned the eggs. The process also happens at Mother Shipton's Cave in North Yorkshire. People hang teddy bears and other items at the entrance to the cave where the petrifying waters then cover them with hard calcium carbonate.
LocalSum: no locality data

ColPhysicalDescription: Achanarella trewini Newman, collected from the Caithness Flagstone Group of Middle Devonian age from Achanarras Quarry, Caithness, Scotland. Collected by Major P.W. Murray-Threipland between 1931 and 1949.
NarNarrative: Achanarella trewini is a vertebrate (animal with a back bone). It has a torpedo shaped body, but no jaw. Exactly what kind of animal Achanarella is, is not known, but it may be a fish. It is found with the fossils of other fish that lived in Lake Orcadie, a large inland lake that covered part of Northern Scotland approximately 380 million years ago.
GeoRock: Caithness Flagstone Group (Upper) & Achanarras Limestone Member
ComName_tab: achanarella & trewini (newman 2002), Animalia & Chordata & Vertebrata & Pisces & Agnatha
LocalSum: UK, Scotland, Caithness, Spittal (2km west north west of), Achanarras

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil fish, Coccosteus, collected from the Caithness Flagstone Group of Middle Devonian age from Achanarras Quarry, Caithness, Scotland. Collected by Major P.W. Murray-Threipland between 1931 and 1949.
GeoRock: Caithness Flagstone Group (Upper) & Achanarras Limestone Member
LocalSum: UK, Scotland, Caithness, Spittal (2km west north west of), Achanarras

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod, Planobina euomphalus, collected from the Perforata Zone, Solent Group, Headon Hill Formation, Headon Beds Member of Tertiary, Oligocene age from Headon Hill, Isle of Wight, Hampshire (SE England).
NarNarrative: This snail is unusual because it has a fairly flat shell with a left-handed coil (most snails have a right-handed coil). It usually lived in fresh water and is often used to identify rocks that were deposited in fresh water. This specimen was found in rocks deposited in fresh and brackish (slightly salty) water lagoons, rivers and lakes that formed in flat low-lying land close to the coast when the climate was subtropical.
GeoRock: Solent Group & Headon Hill Formation & Headon Beds Member
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Hampshire (SE England), Isle of Wight, Headon Hill

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Venus casina, collected from the Red Crag of Quaternary, Early Pleistocene age from Suffolk (SE England).
NarNarrative: The outside of this common bivalve is covered with even-spaced lamellae (ridges). Mya lived in a vertical position in a burrow about 5 centimetres deep on sandy seabeds in coastal areas including the intertidal zone (the area between high and low tide). There is a gap between the two shells where a leathery siphon (tube) reached up to the seabed so that it could suck in water that contained oxygen and food. When the bivalve died its two shells were usually held together by the burrow.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Suffolk (SE England)

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil fish (tooth), Ptychodus sp., collected from the Chalk Formation of Late Cretaceous, Cenomanian - Campanian age.
NarNarrative: Teeth are extremely durable and often provide the only evidence of fish in the fossil record. This flat tooth with ridges running across the crown is from the extinct shark Ptychodus that grew up to 5m long. It would have been part of a complex interlocking "pavement" known as a jaw-plate which contained over a hundred similar teeth. The shark was a predator that fed on shellfish that were crushed between the flat teeth before being swallowed.
LocalSum: no locality data

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Glycymeris glycymeris, collected from the Coralline Crag of Tertiary, Pliocene age from Suffolk (SE England).
NarNarrative: This round bivalve has equally sized convex (outward curving) shell. It lived in a vertical position buried in the surface of the sea floor with the pointed ends (umbones) facing to the side. Siphons (tubes) ran from inside the shell to the sea floor and were used to pump water through its body. Glycymeris fed on tiny food particles that it filtered out of the water.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Suffolk (SE England)

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil crustacean (Barnacle) Balanus sp., encrusting a bivalve, Cyrena sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary, Eocene or Oligocene age from Bembridge, Isle of Wight, Hampshire (SE England). Barnacles encrusting bivalve.
NarNarrative: Barnacles are a special type of crustacean (the same group of animals as crabs and lobsters). They are able to live in areas where the sea waves beat against the rocks. They live cemented (stuck) to rocks or the shells of bivalves and other animals on the sea floor. Cyrena is a bivalve shellfish that lived in a burrow. After the bivalve died its two shells separated. The barnacles then grew on the empty shell. Both animals fed on tiny food particles that they filtered out of the sea water.
ComName_tab: Barnacle, balanus sp., Animalia Invertebrata Arthropoda Crustacea
LocalSum: UK, England, Hampshire (SE England), Isle of Wight, Bembridge

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, Hamites sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Early (?) Cretaceous age.
NarNarrative: This unusual ammonite shell has two straight sections joined by a U-bend and is covered with widely spaced simple ribs. The animal itself (which looked like a small octopus) lived in the wider end of the shell. The reason for this unusual shape is unclear but it may be an adaptation for living on the sea floor (ammonites are usually free-swimming). Hamites lived all over the world in the Cretaceous period before it became extinct towards the end of the period, along with animal like the dinosaurs.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: no locality data

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve (oyster), Rastellum carinatum, collected from the Mantelli Zone, Cambridge Greensand of Late Cretaceous, Early Cenomanian age from Cambridgeshire (SE England).
NarNarrative: This oyster shell has wide, angled ribs that have led to it being called the 'denture clam'. The zig-zag join between the two shells stopped coarse dirt and debris entering the shell and damaging its soft body. Like modern oysters it lived in shallow coastal waters including the intertidal zone (the area between high and low tide) and fed on food particles that it filtered out of the sea water. When this oyster died and its two shells separated before one was preserved in the beach deposit where it was found.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Cambridgeshire (SE England)
no locality data

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod (snail), a Portland Screw, Aptyxiella portlandica, collected from the Portland Stone of Late Jurassic, Tithonian age from Dorset (SW England).
NarNarrative: This specimen is a limestone cast of the inside of a sea snail shell. The original shell formed the mould and was later dissolved away by weakly acidic water. The cast shows that the inside of the shell was very smooth. The slender shape, appearance and the locality where it was found have led the fossil being commonly known as a Portland Screw. The gastropod lived in shallow coastal waters of a warm subtropical sea.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Dorset (SW England)

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil brachiopod, Terebratula sp., collected rom the Chalk Formation of Late Cretaceous age.
NarNarrative: The shell of this fossil brachiopod is very smooth, the only markings on it are fine growth lines. When it was alive it was attached to the sea floor by a pedicle (fleshy stalk) which grew through the hole in the larger of the two shells. Terebratula lived in quiet, shallow, offshore waters where it often formed small colonies. It fed on tiny food particles that it filtered out of the sea water.
ComName_tab: Lamp Shell, terebratula sp., Animalia Invertebrata Brachiopoda
LocalSum: no locality data

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil crustacean (crab), Titanocarcinus sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary, Oligocene age from Limbourge, Belgium. Collected by David M. Lumsden.
NarNarrative: Crabs are well known crustaceans that are found in coastal areas. They have a tough exoskeleton (a hard outer shell) made out of chitin, a material similar to finger nails. They are predators and feed mainly on shellfish that they break open with their claws. The specimen is a well-preserved body carapace (shell) covered with small protective spikes. There are no legs or claws attached to the carapace suggesting that it may be one that was shed when the crab moulted (replaced it shell) during growth.
ComName_tab: Crab, titanocarcinus sp., Animalia Invertebrata Arthropoda Crustacea
LocalSum: Europe, Belgium, Limbourge

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil insect, unidentified, collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary, Oligocene, Rupelian (= Stampian) age from Apt, Stampian Provence, France. Collected by David M. Lumsden.
NarNarrative: These two different flies have been preserved as fossils in freshwater lake sediments. Specimen a shows a dipteron type fly (like a house fly) that has a large segmented (divided) abdomen (lower part of the body), a smaller thorax (upper part of the body) with three of its six legs attached, head and wings. Specimen b looks like a crane fly or mosquito with its long thin body, rounded thorax, fine elongate wings and two small antennae. The flies were probably part of a large insect population in the sub-tropical forests that surrounded the lake.
LocalSum: Europe, France, Stampian Provence, Apt

NarNarrative: This bird feather has been preserved in fine-grained freshwater lake sediments. Although it is unclear how the feather found its way into the lake it does show that bird life was present in the subtropical forests that covered the surrounding land. Bird feathers are quite rare fossils.

NarNarrative: This smooth, round brachiopod shell with growth lines, is a Southern Hemisphere species. In life it was attached to the sea floor by a pedicle (fleshy stalk) that grew from the round hole in the pointed tip of the shell. Like most brachiopods in probably lived in an open sea where the salinity (salt content) was normal. It fed on tiny food particles that it filtered out of the sea water.
ComName_tab: Lamp Shell, liothyrella landonensis, Brachiopod Articulata

NarNarrative: These teeth were found in a world famous fossil locality in the 'badlands' of South Dakota in the mid-west of the USA. At the time the rocks were being deposited the climate was changing and subtropical forests were giving way to open savannah type grassland where the mammals thrived. The soft body tissues and organs of the Rhinoceros would have been eaten by a variety of predators and scavengers before the bones rotted away leaving only the teeth.
SciName: Animalia & Chordata & Vertebrata & Mammalia : : : Mammalia : Chordata

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil echinoid (sea urchin), Echinus sp., collected from the Coralline Crag or Red Crag of Tertiary, Pliocene (or Pleistocene ?) age from Suffolk (SE England).
NarNarrative: In life, the test (skeleton) of this fossil sea urchin was covered with spines. The spines helped the sea urchin move and provided protection from predators. The hole in the base of the test contained a toothed feeding apparatus that surrounded the mouth. It fed on living and dead animals that it found on the sea floor. Echinus has survived to the present day and is found in coastal waters around the British Isles.
GeoAge: Tertiary & Pliocene or Quaternary & Pleistocene (?) / 0 - 5.3 my (c)

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil brachiopod (Lamp Shell), Terebratula sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary age.
NarNarrative: This oval brachiopod (lamp shell) has a smooth shell with fine regularly spaced growth lines. It lived in a warm, shallow sea where it was attached to the sea floor by a pedicle (fleshy stalk) that grew through the round hole in the pointed tip of the shell. It fed on microscopic animals and tiny food particles that it filtered out of the water.
ComName_tab: Lamp Shell, terebratula sp., Animalia Invertebrata Brachiopoda

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod, Pyrula rustica, collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary age from Bordeaux, France. Collected by Charlton.
NarNarrative: This shell has an unusually long tube that ran from the round chamber that protected the sea snail's soft body. The tube contained the snail's inhalant siphon that piped water and nutrients to the gills and prevented it being mixed up with waste water pumped out of the body. Pyrula lived in a warm, shallow sea and fed on microscopic food particles that it filtered out of the water.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Mya sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary, Miocene age from Bordeaux, France. Collected by Charlton.
NarNarrative: This bivalve has similar sized convex (outward curving) shells with concentric lamellae (ridges) and faint growth lines. Mya lived at the bottom of a deep burrow. It had a leathery tube that ran through a gap between the shells up to the seabed. It used this tube to maintain a supply of water for oxygen and food. It fed on microscopic food particles that it filtered out of the water. When the animal died its two shells were usually held together by the burrow.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia & Heterodonta & Myoida : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod, Ficula reticulata, collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary, Miocene age from Bordeaux, France. Collected by Charlton.
NarNarrative: The shape of this sea snail has lead to it commonly being called a fig shell because it looks like the fruit. The coiled shell narrows into a short tube that provided protection for the siphon tube which took water into the snails' body. The snail lived on the muddy floor of a warm, subtropical sea and was part of a rich and varied bivalve and gastropod community.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: Europe, France, Bordeaux

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Cardita sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary, Miocene age from Bordeaux, France. Collected by Charlton.
NarNarrative: This bivalve's shell has a pattern of wide ridges and narrow grooves. Cardita lived in shallow coastal areas where it burrowed into the surface of sandy seabeds and fed on tiny food particles that it filtered out of the water. The bivalve pushed a short leathery tube up to the seabed when its shell was opened. The tube contained two siphons, one supplied the snail with water, oxygen and food and the other removed waste out of the snail.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca
LocalSum: Europe, France, Bordeaux

NarNarrative: This bivalve has adapted to burrowing into wood. Living relatives are often called shipworms even though they are not true worms. The shells are much reduced in size and the body is barely recognisable as a bivalve. The shells are used as tools to drill circular burrows that were then lined with the mineral calcite. The cellulose in the wood is digested as food although they fed mainly on tiny food particles that they filtered out of the water.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

NarNarrative: This living bivalve is better known by its earlier name of Unio littoralis. The equally sized shells are covered in growth lines. It lived on or partly buried in the surface of freshwater sediments and fed on tiny food particles that it filtered out of the water. Potomida has an unusual life cycle; its larvae are parasitic and live on fish before they emerge as young animals, which helps distribute the mussel.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Cambridgeshire (SE England), Cambridge, Barnwell

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Mya truncata, collected from the Clyde Beds of Quaternary, Pleistocene, Late Devensian, Windermere Interstadial age from Scotland. Collected by H. Crosskey.
NarNarrative: This bivalve shellfish has two similar shaped shells covered with faint growth lines. There is a large gap between the two shells which gives the bivalve its common name of 'blunt gaper'. Mya lived at the bottom of a deep burrow on mixed sand and mud seabeds. It had a leathery siphon (tube) that extended through the gap up to the seabed. The siphon supplied water with oxygen and tiny food particles for the animal to live.
GeoAge: Quaternary & Pleistocene & Devensian (Late) & Windermere Interstadial / 10,200 - 13,780 years
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod (limpet), Patella lamarkii, collected from the Marine Calcareous Beds of Tertiary, Pliocene age from Sicily.
NarNarrative: This gastropod is unusual because its shell is a simple cone. It is well adapted to life in the high energy (rough water) environment of the intertidal zone (the area between high and low tide) where it clings to rocks with the sole of its rounded foot. The shell provides protection from predators and stops the soft bodied animal drying up when the tide is out. When covered with water the limpet moves around and grazes on algae. The species is named after the French naturalist and evolutionist Lamarck.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: Sicily

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod, Cassidaria sp., collected from the Marine Calcareous Beds of Tertiary, Pliocene age from Sicily.
NarNarrative: The shape of this sea snail's thick shell has lead to it being called a 'helmet shell' or 'bonnet'. The outside of the shell has a pattern of spiral cords (rope-like pattern) and nodes. Present day relatives live in coastal areas of shallow, tropical and cool, temperate seas. They are active predators on sandy and rocky shores ands feed mainly on bivalves. Some larger forms are prized for carving cameos.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: Sicily

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil crustacean (crab), Trichopeltiaion greggi, collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary, Pliocene age from Canterbury, New Zealand. Collected by David M. Lumsden.
NarNarrative: The claw and part of the abdomen of this crab has been preserved in a calcareous nodule (a limy growth in the rock). Crabs are well known crustaceans that have a tough exoskeleton ) external shell) made out of a material called chitin that is similar to finger nails. The skeleton protects them in the high energy (rough water) shoreline environments. They are predators and feed mainly on bivalves and gastropods that they break open with their claws. Crabs are fairly common fossils in soft Tertiary sedimentary rocks.
ComName_tab: Crab, trichopeltiaion greggi, Animalia Invertebrata Arthropoda Crustacea
LocalSum: Australasia, New Zealand, Canterbury

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bryozoan (sea mat or moss animal), Theona globosa, collected from the Coralline Crag of Tertiary, Pliocene age from Orford, Suffolk (SE England). Collected by William K. Loftus.
NarNarrative: The skeleton of this bryozoan colony, as its name suggests, is globe shaped. It consists of a lot of calcareous (made of calcium carbonate) tubes that were made by the thousands of microscopic animals called zooids that lived in them. The zooids fed on tiny microscopic plants known as phytoplankton that they trapped in their tentacles. Like most bryozoans this colony lived in shallow water at depths between 20 and 80m where their phytoplankton food was most commonly found.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Suffolk (SE England), Orford

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bryozoan (sea mat or moss animal), Meandropora aurantium, collected from the Coralline Crag (?) of Tertiary, Pliocene (?) age from Aldborough, Suffolk (SE England). On wood label.
NarNarrative: The skeleton of this globe-shaped bryozoan colony is made up of many hexagonal (six-sided) calcareous (made of calcium carbonate) tubes arranged in a honeycomb pattern. The tubes were built by the thousands of microscopic animals called zooids that lived in the colony. The zooids fed on tiny microscopic plants known as phytoplankton that they trapped in their tentacles. Like most bryozoans this colony lived in shallow water at depths between 20 and 80m where their phytoplankton food was most abundant.
ComName_tab: Sea Mat (or Moss Animal), meandropora aurantium, Animalia Invertebrata Bryozoa
LocalSum: UK, England, Suffolk (SE England), Aldborough

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of two fossil bryozoa (sea mat or moss animal), Retepora cellulosa, and Retepora simplex (Johnston), collected from the Coralline Crag of Tertiary, Pliocene age from Aldborough, Suffolk (SE England).

The tubes were built by the thousands of microscopic animals called zooids that lived in the colony. The zooids fed on tiny microscopic plants known as phytoplankton that they trapped in their tentacles. Like most bryozoans this colony lived in shallow water at depths between 20 and 80m where their phytoplankton food was most abundant.

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, unidentified, collected from unspecified rocks of Late Triassic, Rhaetic age from the coast at Penarth, Cardiff, Glamorgan (Wales). Collected by Emma Smith.
NarNarrative: These small bivalves (sea shells) are from rocks of Rhaetic (Late Triassic) age. During much of the Triassic, Northern Europe had a hot, dry climate. Rising sea levels at the end of the Triassic period led to an increase in sea-living animals, including bivalves.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca
