ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Trigonia juddiana, collected from the Kimmeridge Clay of Late Jurassic, Kimmeridgian age from Market Raisen, Lincolnshire (Midland England). Possibly collected by Richard Howse.
NarNarrative: This bivalve (meaning two valves or shells), has a very thick shell. Today, it can still be found living off the coast of Australia. During the Jurassic period, when the UK was closer to the Equator, the sea was warmer. The temperature of sea water is a strong influence on the kind of animals that live in it. Often, a greater variety of life will be found in warmer seas.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Lincolnshire (Midland England), Market Rasen

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil crustacean (lobster), Paraglyphea rostra, collected from the Corallian Beds of Late Jurassic, Oxfordian age from Jack Lions Pit, Malton, Yorkshire (NE England). Collected by D.M. Lumsden.
NarNarrative: Only a small part of the lobster has been fossilised. The head, claws, legs and tail are missing. This may be because the lobster broke up after it died, or because parts of the fossil broke off more recently. This fossil lobster would have looked quite similar to modern lobsters.
ComName_tab: , paraglyphea rostra, Animalia Invertebrata Arthropoda Crustacea Malacostraca
LocalSum: UK, England, North Yorkshire (NE England), Malton, Jack Lions Pit

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil belemnite, Megateuthis paxillosus, collected from the Lower Lias of Early Jurassic age from Blockley, Gloucestershire (SW England). Collected by D.M. Lumsden.
NarNarrative: This fossil is from a belemnite, a squid-like animal that lived in the sea. The remains of belemnites have been found inside the stomachs of ichthyosaurs, large marine (sea-living)reptiles that looked a bit like dolphins. The part of a belemnite that is usually found as a fossil is called the guard, and it looks a bit like a large bullet. This fossil is actually the phragmocone, the section of the shell that held the soft body of the belemnite which lies just in front of the guard.
ComName_tab: , megateuthis paxillosus, Animalia Invertebrata Mollusca Cephalopoda Belemnoidea
LocalSum: UK, England, Gloucestershire (SW England), Blockley

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil blastoid, Pentremites godoni, collected from unspecified rocks of Early Carboniferous, Mississippian age from Wax, Kentucky, USA. Collected by David M. Lumsden. Three calyx.
NarNarrative: Pentremites is one of the best known Blastoids, an extinct group of echinoderms. The bud-shaped calyx (the body) has five-sided symmetry and contained the animals' organs. It was attached to the sea floor by a stalk and had a crown of delicate arms that it used to collect food particles. The mouth is in the centre of the top surrounded by five circular holes known as spiracles one of which contains the anus. Blastoids are most commonly found in shallow water reef communities.
LocalSum: North America, USA, Kentucky, Grayson, Wax

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Unicardium sp., collected from the Cornbrash rocks of Middle to Late Jurassic age from Rushden (?), Northamptonshire (Midland England).
NarNarrative: Unicardium is a bivalve seashell (meaning two shells or valves). Cardium means 'of the heart'. The name was probably given to these shells because, when the two joined shells are viewed from the side, they have a heart-like shape. This fossil is a cast of the inside of the shell. Fossils of the outside of shells are more common. If you look closely, you can see that there are no fine lines or decoration on the surface of this fossil, which you would see if this was showing the outside of the shell. Casts like these form when the inside of the shell fills with mud or sand which eventually hardens. When the actual shell around this dissolves away the intenal cast is left behind. Sometimes you can see details of the surface of the inside of the shell such as areas where the muscles were attached.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Northamptonshire (Midland England), Rushden (?)

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Pleuromya costata, collected from the Lias of Early Jurassic age from North Yorkshire (NE England). Collected by Albany Hancock (et.al.).
NarNarrative: Pleuromya costata is a bivalve (meaning two valves or shells), from rocks of early Jurassic age. Pleuromya lived below the sea floor, buried in layers of mud or silt (which is finer than sand). It used a siphon (a tube), that stuck out between its shells, and up into the water above the sea floor, to suck in its food. Modern relatives of this shell fish feed on tiny plants and animals that live in sea water.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, North Yorkshire

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, Cadoceras sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Jurassic (?) age. Single shell showing suture in places.
NarNarrative: Cadoceras is an ammonite that has a very rounded shape. This shape is quite unusual, as the shells of most ammonites are much flatter. Ammonites lived in the sea, and moved around by using a jet-propulsion system, which means that they squirted water out of their shells, to help them travel in the opposite direction. Ammonites were similar to the modern Nautilus that lives in the warm waters of the Pacific Ocean. They were eaten by large marine reptiles such as the dolphin-like ichthyosaurs, which were alive at the same time as the dinosaurs.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: no locality data

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve (oyster), Gryphaea bilobata, collected from the Kellaways Rock of Late Jurassic, Callovian age.
NarNarrative: Gryphaea bilobata is related to the modern oyster. The two shells of this fossil have very different shapes. The larger shell is curved, and quite thick. The smaller shell is flat. In the early part of its life, this shellfish would have attached itself to the seabed or some other hard surface. Gryphea bilobata would have spent its adult life living unattached on the sea floor, partly buried in the sand or mud.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca
LocalSum: no locality data

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, Harpoceratoides strangwaysi, collected from the Falciferum Zone, Upper Lias rocks of Early Jurassic age. Single shell.
NarNarrative: Haropoceratoides strangwaysi is an ammonite from rocks of early Jurassic age. The suture lines (the joins between the sections that make up the shell) show up as pale grey lines on the surface of this fossil, and are very clear. Suture lines form as the ammonite grows, and sometimes look very 'frilly'.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: no locality data

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Plagiostoma lacoruscula, collected from the Corallian Oolite of Late (?) Jurassic, Oxfordian (?) age from Malton, Yorkshire (NE England).
NarNarrative: Plagiostoma lacoruscula is a bivalve (meaning two valves or shells). Plagiostoma usually lived on the seabed, and used fine thread-like outgrowths (called a byssus), to anchor themselves to either the sea floor, or sometimes another shell. They probably got their food by filtering sea water for small particles.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, North Yorkshire (NE England), Malton

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, Promicroceras planicosta, collected from the Obtusum Zone, Lower Lias rocks of Early Jurassic age from Marston Magna, near Yeovil, Somerset (SW England). Monospecific ammonite coquina.
NarNarrative: Fossilised shells piled together like these ammonites are described as a 'death assemblage'. Ammonites swam in the sea, and would only form a group like this after they had died and fallen to the sea bed. Some of these ammonites are partly coated in a shiny pale-coloured material. This has replaced the shells of the ammonites.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Somerset (SW England), Yeovil (nr.), Marston Magna

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Mactromya arenacea, collected from the Lower Lias rocks of Early Jurassic age at Blockley, Gloucestershire. Collected by D.M. Lumsden.
NarNarrative: Mactromya arenacea was a bivalve (meaning two shells or valves)that lived buried in soft mud. This bivalve would have got its food by filtering sea water through a long siphon that passed from its shells and up out of its burrow, where the current would have allowed food particles in the sea water to enter the siphon. Waste materials were passed out through a second siphon.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Gloucestershire (SW England), Blockley

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil reptile, Homoeosaurus sp., collected from the Solenhofen Plattenkalk of Late Jurassic age from Malm, Bavaria, Germany. Cast in plaster of specimen MCZ 1675. Figured: Romer 1941, Man and the Vertebrates, 6th plate opp. p.118. Romer 1959 Vert. Story p.161. DB 165.
NarNarrative: This is a plaster cast of the fossilised remains of a lizard-like reptile, called Homoeosaurus, from the Solenhofen Limestone of Germany. The closest living relative of Homoeosaurus is the tuatara, a protected species that lives on islands off the coast of New Zealand. The tuatara is regarded as a 'living fossil', as it has hardly changed in more than 150 million years.
ComName_tab: Lizard, homoeosaurus & sp., Animalia & Chordata & Vertebrata & Reptilia
LocalSum: Europe, Germany, Bavaria, Malm

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil fish, unidentified, collected from the Caithness Flagstone Group of Middle Devonian age from Achanarras Quarry, Caithness, Scotland. Collected by Major P.W. Murray-Threipland between 1931 and 1949.
NarNarrative: The diamond-shaped pattern on this rock is part of the scaly body of a fish that lived in Lake Orcadie, a large fresh-water lake that used to be in Northern Scotland. There were many different kinds of fish living in the lake, but we don't know exactly which fish this was, because the head and tail are missing from the fossil.
GeoRock: Caithness Flagstone Group (Upper) & Achanarras Limestone Member
ComName_tab: Shark, palaeoniscid, Animalia & Chordata & Vertebrata & Pisces

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil fish, Pterichthyodes sp., collected from the Caithness Flagstone Group of Middle Devonian age from Achanarras Quarry, Caithness, Scotland. Collected by Major P.W. Murray-Threipland between 1931 and 1949.
NarNarrative: Pterichthyodes is an armoured fish. Only the head (on the left-hand side), and the upper part of the body can be seen. Both were covered with hard, armour-like plates. The pair of long, narrow spikes, either side of and just below the head, are jointed spine-like arms.
GeoRock: Caithness Flagstone Group (Upper) & Achanarras Limestone Member
LocalSum: UK, Scotland, Caithness, Spittal (2km west north west of), Achanarras

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil fish, Pterichthyodes sp., collected from the Caithness Flagstone Group of Middle Devonian age from Achanarras Quarry, Caithness, Scotland. Collected by Major P.W. Murray-Threipland between 1931 and 1949.
NarNarrative: Pterichthyodes was an armoured fish, which means that its body, except its tail, was covered with hard, bony plates. There are no fish like these ones alive today. They became extinct hundreds of millions of years ago, before the dinosaurs were alive. This fish has a pair of jointed bony spines, just behind its head, on either side of its body. It belonged to a group of fish called the Placoderms.
GeoRock: Caithness Flagstone Group (Upper) & Achanarras Limestone Member
ComName_tab: Shark, palaeoniscid, Animalia & Chordata & Vertebrata & Pisces
LocalSum: UK, Scotland, Caithness, Spittal (2km west north west of), Achanarras

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil fish, Glyptolepis sp., collected from the Caithness Flagstone Group of Middle Devonian age from Achanarras Quarry, Caithness, Scotland. Collected by Major P.W. Murray-Threipland between 1931 and 1949.
NarNarrative: Glyptolepis was the top predator (hunter), in Lake Orcadie (a large inland lake that covered the Caithness area of Scotland approximately 380 million years ago). This fish could grow to over 50cm in length, and had sharp teeth. The shape of its body is very similar to that of the modern pike, but they are not directly related.
GeoRock: Caithness Flagstone Group (Upper) & Achanarras Limestone Member
LocalSum: UK, Scotland, Caithness, Spittal (2km west north west of), Achanarras

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, Dactylioceras commune, collected from Upper Lias rocks of Commune Sub-zone, Early Jurassic age. The ammonite has the head of a snake carved at the end of the shell.
NarNarrative: This ammonite has the head of a snake carved at the end of the shell. Ammonites like this one are known as 'snakestones'. Legend has it that ammonites are the remains of snakes that were turned to stone by St. Hilda, on the site where she was building a convent in Whitby. Because there were no heads on these fossils, the local dealers and collector's often carved heads on the ammonites to increase sales.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: no locality data

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, Dactylioceras commune, collected from Upper Lias rocks of Commune Sub-zone, Early Jurassic age.
NarNarrative: Dactylioceras commune is an ammonite that is commonly found on the Yorkshire coast. This is the same kind of ammonite as the snakestone, also in this case, so that you can see what it would have looked like before the snake's head was carved on it. The ribs of Dactylioceras start as a single line and then split into pairs over the edge (keel) of the ammonite, and then turn back to a single line. This is called 'bifurcation'. These rib patterns are often used to tell different species of ammonites apart.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: no locality data

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, Hildoceras bifrons, collected from Upper Lias rocks of Bifrons Zone, Early Jurassic age.
NarNarrative: This common ammonite is often found on the Yorkshire coast. Ammonites were often used to make snakestones. If you look very closely at the shell, you can see the suture lines, which in this case are a pale beige colour. Suture lines mark the boundaries between the different chambers in the shell, and in this case, the lines look quite frilly, like a piece of lace.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: no locality data

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod (snail), a Portland Screw, Aptyxiella portlandica, probably collected from the Portland Stone of Late Jurassic, Tithonian age from Dorset (SW England).
NarNarrative: This gastropod (snail shell) fossil is interesting, because it shows us what the inside of this shell looked like. Usually, we only see the outside of the shell. The shell of this fossil has dissolved away, and we can see the rock inside the shell. Fossils of the insides of long, pointed gastropods like this one are called screwstones.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Dorset (SW England)

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, Dactylioceras commune, collected from Upper Lias rocks of Commune Sub-zone, Jurassic age.
NarNarrative: The shell of this ammonite has been replaced by iron pyrite (fool's gold), which gives it a brassy, slightly metallic appearance. The shells of fossils can be replaced by all sorts of different minerals, some of the more common ones are calcite, quartz and opal. The type of mineral that replaces a fossil shell depends on the type of rock in which the fossil forms, and the conditions it is subjected to while it is buried in the earth's crust.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: no locality data

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil crinoid (Sea Lily), Cyathocrinites sp., collected from the Ford Formation (reef facies) of Late Permian, Zechstein (Durham Province), EZ1 age from Sunderland (?), Tyne and Wear (NE England).
NarNarrative: Crinoids are a group of sea creatures that are still alive today. The majority of crinoids attach themselves to the sea-floor, and have a long, flexible 'stem', with a crown of tentacles at the top. Although crinoids look like plants (which is why they are also known as sea-lilies), they are animals that feed on tiny creatures (plankton). Broken fragments of crinoid stems make up this fossil.
LocalSum: UK, England, Tyne and Wear (NE England), Sunderland (?)

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil echinoid (sea urchin), Micraster sp., collected from the Chalk Formation (?) of Late Cretaceous age.
NarNarrative: Micraster is a heart-shaped sea urchin. This one is white, because it is preserved in chalk, a very pure form of limestone. Fossils like this one have been called Fairy loaves, because it was thought that if a family kept some of these fossils in the house, they would not go short of bread.
LocalSum: no locality data

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil echinoid (sea urchin), Micraster sp., collected from the Chalk Formation (?) of Late Cretaceous age.
NarNarrative: Micraster is a heart-shaped sea urchin. Fossils of this type have been described as Fairy loaves, because they were shaped a bit like loaves of bread. Keeping them in the house was thought to prevent the family from going short of bread. In parts of Southern England, fossil sea urchins were thought to prevent milk going sour, and were sometimes kept in dairies for this reason.
LocalSum: no locality data

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil fish (shark tooth), Carcharodon sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary (?) age from South Carolina, USA Collected by Captain Aitkenhead, 6th October 1885.
NarNarrative: Teeth are the most commonly fossilised parts of sharks, because they are harder than the other parts of the shark's body. Shark bones are quite soft, because they are made of cartilage instead of bone. When a shark dies, its teeth decay more slowly than the other, softer parts of its body. The more slowly parts of a dead animal decay, the more likely they are to be fossilised.
ComName_tab: Shark, carcharodon & sp., Animalia & Chordata & Vertebrata & Pisces
LocalSum: North America, USA, South Carolina

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil fish (shark tooth), Carcharodon sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary (?) age from South Carolina, USA Collected by Captain Aitkenhead, 6th October 1885.
NarNarrative: In Malta, fossilised shark's teeth are known as St. Paul's tongues. St. Paul was shipwrecked on the island as he was travelling to Rome. Legend has it that he was bitten by an adder, which he threw into a fire. He put a curse on the snakes of Malta, turning their tongues to stone and making their venom harmless.
ComName_tab: Shark, carcharodon & sp., Animalia & Chordata & Vertebrata & Pisces
LocalSum: North America, USA, South Carolina

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod, Yunnania tunstallensis, collected from the Ford Formation (reef facies) of Late Permian, Zechstein (Durham Province), EZ1 age from Sunderland (?), Tyne and Wear (NE England).
NarNarrative: Yunnania tunstallensis is a tiny gastropod (sea snail) that looks a bit like a periwinkle. This shell fish lived on a tropical reef, a large underwater colony, teeming with life, in the warm waters of the Zechstein Sea 250 million years ago. This sea stetched between what is now northern England and Poland. Fossils of this type can be found in rocks of Permian age near Sunderland.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Tyne and Wear (NE England), Sunderland (?)

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil brachiopod, unidentified, collected from unspecified rocks.
NarNarrative: Brachiopods are sometimes called 'lamp shells' because the shape of some brachiopods, such as this one, is very similar to that of Roman terracotta lamps (also shown). If you compare the shape of the lamp and the fossilised brachiopod, the general shape of both is very similar. The brachiopod has a hole at the top (the pointed end) like the lamp. In the lamp, this is where a wick (like a candlewick) would be inserted. The lamp is hollow, like the shell.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Brachiopoda & Articulata : : : Articulata : Brachiopoda
LocalSum: no locality data

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Myophorella incurva, collected from the Portland Stone of Late Jurassic, Portlandian age from (?), Dorset (SW England).
NarNarrative: This is an internal cast (showing what the inside of the shell looked like), of the bivalve Myophorella incurva. The shells have been dissolved away, leaving a fossil of the inner surface of the shells. Robert Plot, writing in the 17th century, compared these common fossils to horses heads, with large eyes, ears, and a mane. In Dorset, the local dialect translates 'horses heads' into 'osses 'eds.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Dorset (SW England)

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod, Scaphella (?) & sp., collected from the Red Crag (?) of Tertiary, Early (?) Pleistocene age.
NarNarrative: The fossil on the right is an internal cast (from the inside of the shell), of a gastropod (sea snail) shell. It is similar to the modern shell that is shown on the left. Living gastropods of this type feed on bivalve shells by making a neat hole in the shell of their victim, through which they suck out its body. Internal casts show us what the inside of a fossil shell looked like. These fossils are less common than the ones that show what the outside of a shell looks like.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: no locality data

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Spondylus spinosus, possibly collected from the Chalk Formation of Late Cretaceous age.
NarNarrative: This spiny bivalve shell has been preserved in a flint nodule. Flint nodules often form around the remains of dead animals. The material that forms flint (silica...the same material from which glass is made) is dissolved in the sea water. Spondylus spinosus lived on the seabed, where it used the spines on its shell to help support its weight and keep it firmly on the sea floor.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca
LocalSum: no locality data

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil reptile (crocodile tooth), unidentified, collected from the Headon Hill Formation, Headon Beds of Tertiary, Late Eocene, Priabonian age from Headon or Bembridge, Isle of Wight, Hampshire (SE England). Collected by D. Smith.
NarNarrative: Teeth often provide the only evidence of reptiles and other vertebrates (animals with backbones) in the fossil record because they are extremely tough and durable. The flesh of the crocodile would have been eaten by scavengers and the bones rotted away leaving only the teeth. This tooth was found in rocks deposited in fresh and brackish (slightly salty) water. Often the hard, bony plates (scutes) that cover the crocodile's back are also found as fossils.
ComName_tab: Unidentified Crocodile, Animalia & Chordata & Vertebrata & Reptilia
SciName: Animalia & Chordata & Vertebrata & Reptilia : : : Reptilia : Chordata
LocalSum: UK, England, Hampshire (SE England), Isle of Wight, Headon Hill

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil mammal (tooth), a Mastodon, Anancus anvernensis, collected from unspecified rocks of Quaternary (?) age.
NarNarrative: Mastodons are a group of mammals that evolved from the same ancestors as elephants and mammoths. They were widely distributed throughout the Northern Hemisphere and Africa until they became extinct about 2 million years ago. Climate changes in a glacial episode (ice age) destroyed their forest habitats and the plants they ate. Their name is derived from the shape of their teeth and means 'nipple toothed'. The tooth shape shows that Mastodons fed on the leaves and branches of trees and shrubs.
LocalSum: no locality data

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil mammal (tooth), a Cave Hyaena, Crocuta crocuta spelaea, collected from unspecified rocks of Quaternary, Late Pleistocene, Ipswichian age from Kirkdale Cave, Pickering (nr.), North Yorkshire (NE England). Kirkdale Cave written on specimen.
NarNarrative: Although living hyenas are found in warmer regions of the Old World, fossil remains show that they lived much further north during Quaternary times. As their name suggest they lived in caves and their teeth and bones are found in many cave deposits. The cave where this hyena was found included parts of the skeletons of other animals suggesting that they died elsewhere and the bits were carried back to the cave by the hyenas.
ComName_tab: Cave Hyaena, crocuta & crocuta & spelaea (goldfuss), Animalia & Chordata & Vertebrata & Mammalia
LocalSum: UK, England, North Yorkshire (NE England), Pickering (nr.), Kirkdale Cave

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil mammal (tooth), a Cave Bear, Ursus spelaeus, collected from the Beestonian Zone of Quaternary, Early to Middle Pleistocene age.
NarNarrative: The Cave Bear was about one third larger than the living Brown Bear and found all over northern Eurasia until they became extinct about 70 000 years ago. Climate changes during a glaciation (ice age) destroyed their coniferous (evergreen) forest habitat and food supply. As its name implies the bear lived in caves and so its teeth are often found in cave deposits. In summer the Cave Bear fed mainly on plant foods it found in the coniferous forests.
ComName_tab: Cave Bear, Ursus spelaeus, Ursus spelaeus
SciName: Ursus spelaeus : Ursidae : Carnivora : Mammalia : Chordata
LocalSum: no locality data

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil fish, Diplomystus brevissimus, collected from the 'Fish Beds' of Late Cretaceous, Cenomanian age from Mount Lebanon, Lebanon, Syria. Several well preserved small fish on slab of fine grained calcareous mudstone.
NarNarrative: The bony skeletons and patches of skin of these small herring-lie fish are well preserved in the fine-grained host rock. Like modern herring they lived in shoals near the surface of the sea where they fed on small animals. They grew up to 10cm long. They have been so well preserved because there was no oxygen in the water on the sea floor. This stopped their bodies decaying and also meant that other animals could not eat their bodies.
LocalSum: Syria, Mount Lebanon

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil coral, Palaeosmilia sp., collected from the Carboniferous Limestone (?) of Early (?) Carboniferous, Dinantian (?), Visean (?) age from Ironbridge, Shropshire (Midland England).
NarNarrative: This is the horn-shaped skeleton of a solitary coral (one that doesn't share a skeleton structure with other corals). Palaeosmilia was attached to the sea floor at the pointed end. The living coral polyp occupied the cup shaped hollow at the wide end of the horn. The polyp looked like a sea anemone with a mouth in the centre of a ring of tentacles that it used to capture small animals as food. Like most corals it lived in warm shallow seas near the equator and may have been part of a reef community.
LocalSum: UK, England, Shropshire (Midland England), Ironbridge

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil blastoid, Pentremites pyriformis, collected from unspecified rocks of Early (?) Carboniferous, Mississippian (?) age from Indiana, USA. Collected by David M. Lumsden.
NarNarrative: Pentramites is one of the best known Blastoids, an extinct group of echinoderms (a group that includes star fish and sea urchins). The bud-shaped calyx (cup) has five-sided symmetry (hence the name "pent...") and contained the animal's organs. It was attached to the sea floor by a stalk and had a crown of delicate arms that it used to collect food particles. The mouth is in the centre surrounded by five circular holes known as spiracles, one of which contains the anus. Blastoids usually lived in shallow water reefs.
LocalSum: North America, USA, Indiana

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil assemblage, unidentified, collected from the Much Wenlock Limestone Formation of Silurian, Wenlock, Homerian age from Wren's Nest (?), Dudley, West Midlands (Midland England).
NarNarrative: This limestone is a piece of fossilised seabed. It is packed with hundreds of fossil animals including branching skeletons of bryozoa (moss animals), corals, brachiopods (lamp shells), and fragments of trilobites. This shows that during the Silurian period, Dudley was covered by a shallow sunlit tropical sea crowded with many different kinds of animals.
LocalSum: UK, England, West Midlands (Midland England), Dudley, Wren's Nest

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil fish, Knightia alta, collected from the Green River Formation of Tertiary, Early - Middle Eocene, Ypresian - Lutetian (?) age from Green River, Wyoming, U.S.A.. Collected by David M. Lumsden. Single well preserved fish on slab of calcareous mudstone.
NarNarrative: This freshwater fossil fish comes from Green River in the USA, one of the worlds 'super fossil sites'. It is the state fossil of Wyoming and was named after the first state geologist, Wilbur Clinton Knight. Knightia is a relative of the present day herring and grew to a length of 10 to 25 centimetres. The fish population died out suddenly when oxygen levels fell dramatically. This is the reason that large numbers were preserved in the fine-grained lake sediments.
LocalSum: North America, USA, Wyoming

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil trilobite, a Dudley Locust, Calymene blumenbachi, collected from the Much Wenlock Limestone Formation of Silurian, Wenlock, Homerian age from Wren's Nest, Dudley, West Midlands (Midland England).
NarNarrative: This beautifully preserved trilobite was a very common fossil in the Silurian Limestones quarried at Dudley in the 18th and 19th centuries. It was much prized by collector's and became famously known as the Dudley Locust. It even appears on the Dudley Coat of Arms.
ComName_tab: Dudley Locust, calymene blumenbachi (brongniart 1822), Animalia Invertebrata Arthropoda Trilobita
LocalSum: UK, England, West Midlands (Midland England), Dudley, Wren's Nest

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil cephalopod, Nautilus sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary (?) age from Morroco (?), Africa.
NarNarrative: The spirally coiled shell of this fossil Nautilus has been dissolved away to show the inside structure made of septa (walls) and chambers. The animal lived in the outermost chamber of the shell and the smaller chambers were filled with gas. This made Nautilus buoyant and allowed it to adjust its position in the water by varying the amount of gas in its shell. Nautilus swam using jet propulsion, forcing water out of its body. They were carnivores and fed mainly on shrimps, crabs and fish caught in their tentacles.
ComName_tab: , nautilus sp., Animalia Invertebrata Mollusca Cephalopoda Nautiloidea
ColSum: Johnson, Eric (stratigraphy revised based on information in record)
LocalSum: Morocco

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a trace fossil, unidentified reptilian footprints, collected from unspecified rocks of Triassic age.
NarNarrative: The two rows of footprints on this slab of red sandstone form a track made by an unidentified animal as it walked across sand. It had five toes on each foot. We don't know where this piece of sandstone came from, but it is probably British, and possibly from the Berwick (Northumberland) area. When the animal walked over soft sand it left an impression of its foot. This impression was then filled by another layer of sand which protected the footprint. As the sand hardened to form sandstone, the footprint became a fossil. Fossils of footprints are called 'trace-fossils' because they are not actually the remains of the animal, but rather the marks it left behind.
SciName: Animalia & Chordata & Vertebrata & Reptilia : : : Reptilia : Chordata
LocalSum: no locality data

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil goniatite, Muensteroceras redesdalense Philips, collected from the Redesdale Ironstone, Scremerston Coal Group of Early Carboniferous, Dinantian, Visean, Asbian age from Ridsdale, Northumberland (NE England). Collected by Richard Howse.
NarNarrative: Gonatites were similar to the coiled-shelled ammonites but more primitive. The inside of the shell was divided up by septa (walls) into several separate chambers. The animal was similar to a squid and lived in the outermost chamber and the smaller chambers were filled with gas so that the shell was buoyant. Muensteroceras lived near the surface of the sea and swam using jet propulsion, forcing water out of its body. It was carnivores and fed mainly on shrimps, crabs and fish they caught in their tentacles.
ComName_tab: , muensteroceras redesdalense (phillips), Animalia Invertebrata Mollusca Cephalopoda
LocalSum: UK, England, Northumberland (NE England), Ridsdale

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil fish, Acentrophorus varians Kirkby, collected from the Concretionary Limestone of Late Permian, Zechstein (Durham Province), EZ2 age from Fulwell Hill, Sunderland, Tyne and Wear (NE England). Collected by James Walter Kirkby.
NarNarrative: Acentrophorus varians was a small fish, about the same size as a sardine. It lived in the Zechstein sea (a warm tropical sea), 250 million years ago. Acentophorus was adapted to survive in the very salty water. It was probably a scavenger and fed from the remains of other dead fish. It had tiny sharp, pointed teeth for tearing flesh, but was one of the smallest fish in the sea at that time and was therefore probably not a predator.
ComName_tab: acentrophorus & varians (kirkby), Actinopterygii & Neopterygii & Semionotiformes & Semionotidae
LocalSum: UK, England, Tyne and Wear (NE England), Sunderland, Fulwell Hill

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Anthracosia robusta, collected from the Modiolus Zone, Lower Coal Measures, Busty Seam of Late Carboniferous, Westphalian, Langsettian age from Derwent Pit, Medomsley, Co Durham (NE England).
NarNarrative: These mussels lived in shallow, freshwater lakes and brackish (slightly salty) water lagoons that formed when coastal, coal forming forests were flooded. Like present day mussels they lived in large colonies. They formed important 'mussel bands' in Coal Measures rocks and some can be used to identify individual coal seams. The specimen is from the 'mussel band' that occurred in the roof of the Busty Seam.

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod, Fusinus porrectus, collected from the Barton Group, Barton Clay Formation of Tertiary, Middle Eocene, Lutetian - Bartonian age from Barton, Bournemouth, Hampshire (SE England). Collected by William K. Loftus.
NarNarrative: The thick shell of this slender spindle shaped sea snail is covered with spiral ribs and has a long canal (groove) below the body chamber. The canal provided protection for a siphon (tube) that took water into the snail's body. Fusinus was a scavenger and a predator that fed on dead animals and living bivalves that lived on the seabed. It was part of a community of animals living in a shallow subtropical sea.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Hampshire (SE England), Bournemouth (nr.), Barton

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil crustacean (crab), Xanthopsis tuberculata, collected from the Thames Group, London Clay Formation of Tertiary, Early Eocene, Ypresian age from Isle of Sheppey, Kent (SE England).
NarNarrative: Crabs are well known crustaceans found in a variety of shallow coastal environments. Their tough exoskeleton (outer shell) is made out of chitin, a material similar to finger nails. They are predators and scavengers that feed on bivalves and gastropods that they break open with their claws. Crabs are fairly common fossils particularly in Tertiary sedimentary rocks. The specimen shows the underside of the crab, including parts of the legs and claws.
ComName_tab: Crab, xanthopsis tuberculata, Animalia Invertebrata Arthropoda Crustacea
LocalSum: UK, England, Kent (SE England), Isle of Sheppey

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil fish , Knightia eoceana Cope, collected from the Green River Formation (?) of Tertiary, Early - Middle Eocene, Ypresian - Lutetian (?) age from Green River, Wyoming, USA.
NarNarrative: This freshwater fossil fish comes from the Green River Formation in the USA, one of the worlds 'super fossil sites'. It is the state fossil of Wyoming, and was named after the first state geologist, Wilbur Clinton Knight. Knightia is a relative of the present day herring, and grew to a length of 10 to 25 centimetres. It lived in large shoals. The fish population died out very abruptly and large numbers were preserved in the fine-grained lake sediments.
ComName_tab: knightia & eoceana (cope), Animalia & Chordata & Vertebrata & Pisces
LocalSum: North America, USA, Wyoming, Sweetwater, Green River

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil graptolite, Dicranograptus clingani, collected from the Loweswater Formation, Skiddaw Group of Early Ordovician, Arenig, Moridunian age from Barf, Bassenthwaite, Cumbria (NW England). Collected by Emma Smith.
NarNarrative: Graptolites were a group of marine colonial animals that belong to the group Hemichordata (chordates without a backbone). Most of them floated freely about in the ocean, but some lived attached to the bottom. They lived from the Cambrian to the mid-Carboniferous. As fossils, most of the graptolites look like branches of saw blades, with a length from 10 millimetres up to one metre long. They are usually white or silvery against the dark shale. Each 'saw tooth' was a small tube and housed a small animal. The soft parts of the graptolites have never been found, but we assume that the animal fed by extending a wreath of tentacles to capture food particles.
ComName_tab: , dicranograptus clingani, Animalia Chordata Hemichordata Graptolithina
LocalSum: UK, England, Cumbria (NW England), Bassenthwaite, Barf

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil brachiopod Strophomena sp., collected from the Dufton Shale Formation of Middle Ordovician, Caradoc, Longvillian - Onnian age from Dufton, Cumbria (NW England). Collected by E.J. Garwood.
NarNarrative: Strophomena, a marine shellfish, has a distinctive fan-shaped shell. It is an example of a brachiopod
ComName_tab: Lamp Shell, strophomena sp. (?), Brachiopod Articulata
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Brachiopoda & Articulata : : : Articulata : Brachiopoda

NarNarrative: There are several different kinds of fossils in this rock. The ones which look like miniature saw blades are graptolites. The oval-shaped fossil (lower left) is the head of an extinct shrimp-like creature, Discinocaris. This animal probably lived near the surface of the sea feeding on plankton.

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil trilobite, Agraulos ceticephalus, collected from the 'Stage C Greywacke' of Cambrian age from Skrelg (Bohemia), Czechoslovakia (?).
NarNarrative: Trilobites were sea-dwelling animals many of which scavenged for rotting plant and animal material on the seabed. They became extinct about 248 million years ago at the end of the Permian period. The most closely related animal alive today is the Horseshoe or King Crab which can be found in the Atlantic, Indian and Pacific oceans.
ComName_tab: , agraulos ceticephalus, Animalia Invertebrata Arthropoda Trilobita
LocalSum: Czechoslovakia (?), Skrelg (Bohemia)

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil trace fossil, Chondrites sp., collected from the Skiddaw Group of Early Ordovician, Arenig (?) age from Randale Beck (?), Cumbria (NW England). Collected by John Jeffrey.
NarNarrative: We do not know what animals made these fossilised burrows. They would have lived within the soft mud on the seabed, tunnelling and making the burrows as they searched for food. The burrows were then filled by mud of a different colour. Eventually the mud turned into mudstone and then into slate and the burrows became fossilised.
ComName_tab: Trace Fossil (burrows), chondrites & sp., Animalia & Chordata & Vertebrata
LocalSum: UK, England, Cumbria (NW England), Randale Beck (?)

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil coral, Favosites gothlandicus, collected from the Hudson River Group of Early Silurian, Llandovery - Wenlock age from Frankfort, USA. Collected by McChesney.
LocalSum: North America, USA, Kentucky, Franklin, Frankfort

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod (snail), Pleurotomaria helix, collected from the Trenton Group of Early Silurian, Llandovery - Wenlock age from Ohio River, USA. Collected by McChesney.
NarNarrative: This is the fossilised shell of a snail which lived on the bed of the Silurian sea. Snails were very important scavengers, feeding mainly on the remains of dead animals. Some snails fed on seaweeds which were probably common in the shallower, sunlit parts of the Silurian Sea.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: North America, USA, Ohio River

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil trilobite, Dalmanites myops Konig, collected from the Much Wenlock Limestone Formation of Silurian, Wenlock, Homerian age from Dudley, West Midlands (Midland England).
NarNarrative: Trilobites are very common fossils in the Silurian rocks exposed at Dudley. Looking like overgrown woodlice, they probably crawled over the seabed scavenging for food. Trilobites grew by shedding their shells (moulting) and then growing a new one. This means that moulted fragments are more common as fossils than complete shells. This particular example is a tail, or pygidium, of a trilobite, and probably represents part of a moulted shell.
ComName_tab: , dalmanites myops (konig), Animalia Invertebrata Arthropoda Trilobita
LocalSum: UK, England, West Midlands (Midland England), Dudley

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil fish , Dipterus valenciennesi, collected from the Middle Old Red Sandstone of Devonian age from Banniskirk Quarry, Caithness, Scotland. Collected by Rev G.C. Abbs (?).
NarNarrative: Dipterus is a primitive lungfish that was able to breathe air. It probably lived in water that didn't contain much oxygen. The body of this fish was covered with rounded scales, that show up very clearly on this fossil. Dipterus is related to modern lungfish that live in rivers in Africa, Australia and South America.
LocalSum: UK, Scotland, Caithness (Scotland)

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil sponge, unidentified, collected from unspecified rocks of Devonian age from Boulogne, France. Collected by W.K. Loftus (?).
NarNarrative: Sponges are animals that have a very simple structure. They live ina wide range of water depths, and date back to the Cambrian period, 500 million years ago. They usually live in clear water, and feed by drawing water through their outer wall, extracting food from it, and then passing the water out through a larger opening.
LocalSum: Europe, France, Boulogne

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil crinoid (Sea Lily), Actinocrinites sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Middle Devonian age from Eifel, Rhine, Germany. Collected by W.K. Loftus (?). Crinoid calyx.
NarNarrative: Actinocrinites is a crinoid
LocalSum: Europe, Germany, Rhine, Eifel

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil scaphopod (tusk shell), unidentified, collected from unspecified rocks of Middle Devonian age from Eifel, Rhine, Germany. Collected by W.K. Loftus (?).
NarNarrative: Scaphopods, which are also known as tusk shells (because they are shaped like a tusk), are shellfish that live in the sea. This animal lived with the wider end of the shell buried in the seabed, and the narrower end in the water. This example is from rocks of Devonian age, but scaphopods are more common today than they were in the past.
ComName_tab: Tusk Shell, , Animalia Invertebrata Mollusca Scaphopoda
LocalSum: Europe, Germany, Rhine, Eifel

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod (snail), Murchisonia intermedia, collected from unspecified rocks of Middle Devonian age from Hand, near Paffrath, Germany. Collected by W.K. Loftus.
NarNarrative: Murchisonia intermedia was a gastropod (sea snail) that lived in a tall pointed shell. Gastropods have a muscular foot-like organ, which they use to move around. They feed using their radula (a rough, tongue like organ, made up of many tiny teeth). This gastropod probably spent its life burrowing into the sea floor, in search of food.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: Europe, Germany, Paffrath (nr.), Hand

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil coral, Heliolites porosus, collected from unspecified rocks of Devonian age from ?, Devon (SW England). Collected by William Pengelly.
NarNarrative: Heliolites was a colonial coral (many coral animals living together) that is now extinct. The individual coral animals, also known as polyps, looked a bit like small sea anemones. They lived in tubes made of the mineral calcite, which were joined together to form a colony. In Heliolites, these tubes, called corallites, were separated by smaller tubes that did not contain polyps.
LocalSum: UK, England, Devon (SW England)

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil fish, Ischnacanthus gracilis, collected from the Lower Old Red Sandstone of Devonian age from Turin Hill, Forfarshire (Scotland). Collected by J. Powrie.
NarNarrative: Ischnacanthus gracilis was a fish that had a long, scaly body. This fish had two narrow dorsal spines, one either side of and just behind its head. It was a predatory (hunting) fish, and probably lived in Lake Forfar in Angus, Scotland, a fresh-water lake surrounded by volcanoes. In this specimen the fossil is the dark area, The deep grooves around it are where tools have been used to chisel away the rock.
ComName_tab: ischnacanthus & gracilis (egerton), Animalia & Chordata & Vertebrata & Pisces
LocalSum: UK, Scotland, Fife (Scotland), Turin Hill

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil fish, Coccosteus cuspidatus, collected from unspecified rocks of Middle Devonian age from Lethen Bar, Nairnshire (Scotland). Collected by Thomas Atthey.
NarNarrative: Coccosteus was a Devonian fish that had its head and part of its body covered with bony plates, which can easily be seen in this fossil. This fish was a hunter. The bony plates of its jaw had sharp, serrated edges (a bit like a steak knife), which helped it to tear through the flesh of its prey (the animals that it ate). The tail of Coccosteus is not covered in bony plates, so this part of the fish is less commonly fossilised. (The soft parts often decay before the animal is buried and preserved). Thomas Atthey, who collected this fossil, is better known for his collection of local Carboniferous fish in the Hancock Museum.
ComName_tab: coccosteus & cuspidatus (miller), Animalia & Chordata & Vertebrata & Pisces
LocalSum: UK, Scotland, Highland (Scotland), Lethen Bar

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil fish, Asterolepis maximus, collected from unspecified rocks of Middle Devonian age from Nairn, Inverness-shire (Scotland). Collected by Mr W. Waters.
NarNarrative: Asterolepis maxima was an armoured fish that lived during the Middle to Late Devonian. The upper part of its body and its head were covered with protective bony plates. The plates were covered with a raised pattern of wart like lumps. Asterolepis probably lived on the sea floor, searching for food in layers of mud. This fossil shows the plates that covered the main body of the fish. The head, armoured fins and tail are all missing. Fish like these are very primitive and do not have many of the special adaptations that modern fish have.
ComName_tab: asterolepis & maximus, Animalia & Chordata & Vertebrata & Pisces
LocalSum: UK, Scotland, Highland (Scotland), Nairn

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil fish, Asterolepis maximus, collected from unspecified rocks of Middle Devonian age from Nairn, Nairnshire (Scotland). Collected by W. Waters.
NarNarrative: Asterolepis maxima was a primitive armoured fish, which had bony plates covering its head and the upper part of its body, giving it a box like shape. Fish like this are now extinct, but were quite common during the Middle and Late Devonian. Asterolepis probably live on the sea floor, scavenging in mud for food. This specimen shows one of the armoured plates from the body of the fish. If you look closely you can see that it is covered with many tiny wart-like bumps.
ComName_tab: asterolepis & maximus, Animalia & Chordata & Vertebrata & Pisces
LocalSum: UK, Scotland, Nairnshire (Scotland), Nairn

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Neithea quinquecostata, collected from the Inflatum Zone = Dispar Zone, Upper Greensand Formation of Cretaceous, Late Albian age from Warminster, Wiltshire (SW England).
NarNarrative: This scallop takes its species name from the five (quin) main ribs(costata) that strengthen the convex (outward curving) shell. The scallop lived on a sandy seabed in shallow coastal waters below. It was able to swim by clapping its two valves together to force out jets of water. It usually only did this to escape from predators such as fish. It fed on tiny food particles that it filtered out of the water.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Wiltshire (SW England), Warminster

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil foraminifera, Loftusia persica Brady, collected from the Lower Tertiary Limestone of Tertiary age from Kellapstun Pass (Bakhtiyari Mountains), Du Pulun (nr.), Iran. Collected by William K. Loftus.
NarNarrative: Foraminifera are sea-living microfossils (microscopic-sized fossils) that secrete a hard calcareous (made of calcite) skeleton known as a test. Loftusia is quite large and has a flat, spirally coiled shell. It lived on the floor of a warm shallow sea, often in such great numbers that the tests later formed limestones like the one shown here. Foraminifera changed (evolved) very quickly through time. This means that they can be used to identify different rocks layers, as distinct species are only found in certain layers.
LocalSum: Iran, Du Pulun (nr.), Kellapstun Pass (Bakhtiyari Mountains)

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil fish, a Coelacanth, Coelacanthus granulatus, collected from the Marl Slate of Late Permian, Zechstein (Durham Province), EZ1 age.
NarNarrative: Coelacanthus granulatus was a fish that probably used its well-developed limb-like fins for crawling along the seabed as well as swimming. It was thought that coelacanths became extinct about 100 million years ago until a fisherman caught a live one off the coast of South Africa in 1938! They are still being caught today and are known as living fossils. Modern Ceolacanths are much larger than their earlier relatives. Many fossils of Coelacanths have been found in the local Marl Slate rocks of Co. Durham, but they are still quite rare.
ComName_tab: Coelacanth, coelacanthus & granulatus, Sarcopterygii & Crossoptergyii (After Romer)
LocalSum: no locality data

ColPhysicalDescription: specimen of a fossil brachiopod lamp shell, Cyrtia exporrecta, collected from the Much Wenlock Limestone Formation of Silurian, Wenlock, Homerian age from Dudley, West Midlands (Midland England). Collected by Emma Smith. With C. epifauna.
NarNarrative: Brachiopods are animals which live in or on the seabed. Although fairly rare in present day seas, their fossilised shells are very common in Silurian rocks and show an amazing variety of different shapes. The animal was protected by two shells hinged at the pointed end. Sometimes, as in this example, the two shells are very different in shape and form. This view of the back of the two shells shows a top shell which is fairly flat but the lower shell has much more of a triangular shape. Such a curious difference of shape suggests a specialised way of life which we can only guess at as this kind of brachiopod became extinct millions of years ago.
ComName_tab: Lamp Shell, cyrtia exporrecta (wahlenberg), Brachiopod Articulata
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Brachiopoda & Articulata : : : Articulata : Brachiopoda
LocalSum: UK, England, West Midlands (Midland England), Dudley

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil coral, Labechia conferta Lonsdale, collected from the Much Wenlock Limestone Formation (?) of Silurian, Wenlock, Homerian age from Dudley, West Midlands (Midland England).
NarNarrative: This is the bottom view of a fossilised colonial coral and shows how the colony grew. A single coral animal (polyp) would have settled on the seabed and formed a tiny tube of calcium carbonate in which to live. This forms the pointed part in the middle of the photograph. The animal would have reproduced by a process of budding so that two tubes would have formed. Each of these would have budded again to form four. This process would have been repeated many times over and over again so that eventually a cushion-shaped skeleton consisting of thousands of tubes was formed. When the coral polyps died, the hard calcium carbonate skeleton remained and became part of the limestone rock forming on the seabed. These Silurian limestones underly much of Dudley. They are a rich source of fossil corals and other animals that lived and died in the sunlit tropical Silurian sea.
LocalSum: UK, England, West Midlands (Midland England), Dudley

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil gastropod (snail), Euomphalopterus sp., collected from the Much Wenlock Limestone Formation (?) of Silurian, Wenlock, Homerian age.
NarNarrative: These are the fossilised shells of snails which lived on the bed of the Silurian sea. Snails were very important scavengers on the Silurian reefs, feeding mainly on the remains of dead animals. Some snails fed on seaweeds which were also probably common in the shallower, sunlit parts of the Silurian Sea.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Gastropoda : : : Gastropoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: no locality data

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil fish (spine), Xenacanthus sp., collected from the Modiolaris Zone, Middle Coal Measures, Low Main Seam of Late Carboniferous, Westphalian, Duckmantian age from Newsham Colliery, Blyth, Northumberland (NE England). Spine.
NarNarrative: This spine was attached to the back of the head of the small freshwater shark Xenacanthus that grew up to 70cm in length. The fish had a slim narrow body with a continuous fin along its back and looked like a modern conger-eel. It lived in freshwater swamps where it hunted smaller fish for food. The narrow body helped it swim through the closely spaced swamp plants. The spine is often all that is found of the fish.
GeoRock: Coal Measures Formation (Middle) & Low Main Seam

Platysomus had blunt cone-shaped teeth, ideal for crushing and eating shellfish. Fossils of this fish are less common than those of the herring like Palaeoniscum that lived in shoals.

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil coral, Lonsdaleia floriformis var. laticlavia, collected from the Millstone Grit Group, Great Limestone of Early Carboniferous, Namurian, Pendleian age from Greenleighton, Northumberland (NE England). Collected by Sir W.C. Trevelyan.
NarNarrative: This coral colony is made up of angular corallites (individual coral skeletons) that are in close contact with each other. Each corallite has a well-defined centre (axial column) that looks like a flower and gives the species' its name. A living coral polyp occupied the hollow in each corallite. The polyp was similar to a sea anemone with a mouth in the centre of a ring of tentacles, which it used to capture small animals as food. Like most corals it lived attached to the floor of warm shallow seas near the equator.

NarNarrative: The bones of most land vertebrates rot away after the carcase (body) has been eaten by other scavenging animals. This Red Deer lower jaw bone with teeth has been preserved in a peat bog where the low oxygen environment stops the destructive bacteria from destroying the bone. This specimen is barely old enough to be a fossil if it is the same age as the 5 000 to 8 000 year-old peat that it was found in.

NarNarrative: The two parallel rows of marks on this piece of rock are the fossilised footprints of an animal. Fossils like this one are called trace fossils, because they are the marks made by some animal that died long ago. Unfortunately, we don't know what kind of animal made these footprints. Because the footprints are so close together, they were probably made by a small animal that walked on four legs.

NarNarrative: This delicate ridged shell is a fossilised brachiopod. If you look closely, you can see a small circular hole near the top of the shell, which has filled up after the animal died and was buried. Through this small hole, a fleshy anchoring 'stem' known as the pedicle protruded, with which the brachiopod anchored itself to a hard surface on the sea floor.

NarNarrative: This fossil is a gastropod (sea snail). Gastropods lived inside coiled shells. Purpuroidea crawled over the surface of the seabed, as it searched for food, on a muscular 'foot' that protruded from the hole in its shell. This gastropod is often found in rocks that were formed in areas where the sea floor was unstable. These were conditions that many other animals would not have been able to survive.

NarNarrative: Diplomystus dentatus was a common, now extinct, herring-like fish that lived during the Eocene period, approximately 40 to 50 million years ago, in a deep fresh water lake that covered an area of approximately 25000 miles of the USA. At that time, the climate in the area was sub tropical. Diplomystus probably ate small fish that also lived in the lake, because fossils of this fish, with smaller fish in its mouth and stomach, have been found. The rock from which this fossil comes from is part of the Green River Formation.

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil annelid (worm), Lumbricaria sp., collected from the Lithographic Limestone of Late Jurassic age from Solenhofen, Bavaria, Germany.
NarNarrative: The long dark shape on one of these two pieces of rock is a fossil of a worm. The groove on the other piece of rock fits over the top of the worm, because this bit of rock rests on top of the piece that contains the fossil. It is unusual to find a fossilised worm. Fossils of shells and bones are much more common, because they are hard, and don't decay quickly. Soft animals like worms have no hard parts such as bones or shells, and usually decay too quickly to become fossils.

NarNarrative: Stephanoceras eugenii is an ammonite from the Oxford Clay. The rusty orange colour of this fossil is caused by a high concentration of iron in the rock which it is found in. Ammonites lived in the sea, and were eaten by large marine reptile such as ichthyosaurs, that looked a bit like dolphins. Ammonites were alive at the same time as the dinosaurs, and became extinct at the same time, 65 million years ago.

Ammonites lived in the sea, and were probably eaten by the larger animals that lived there, for example, ichthyosaurs, large marine reptiles that looked a bit like dolphins. This ammonite has a brassy colour, because its shell has been replaced by the mineral iron pyrite (fool's gold).

NarNarrative: Nautilus is related to the modern Pearly Nautilus which lives in the Pacific Ocean today. On the surface of this fossil, the suture lines, which mark the growth stages of the animal, can be clearly seen. The suture line of Nautilus is much simpler than that of the ammonites, for example, Phylloceras and Hildoceras. This fossil was found in Lower Jurassic rocks in Yorkshire.

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, Kosmoceras phaeinum, collected from unspecified rocks of Late Jurassic, Callovian age.
NarNarrative: Kosmoceras phaeinum was an ammonite that lived approximately 160 million years ago. Although ammonites became extinct 65 million years ago, the same time as the dinosaurs, they probably looked very similar to the modern Nautilus that lives in the Pacific Ocean. This ammonite is unusal because it has lappets (thin rectangular projections) on its shell. You can only see one lappet (there would have been two).
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: no locality data

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, Hildoceras bifrons, collected from the Bifrons Zone, Upper Lias of Early Jurassic age.
NarNarrative: Hildoceras bifrons was an ammonite that lived during the early Jurassic period, approximately 200 million years ago. If you look closely, you will see that this fossil has some very fine lace-like white markings on its surface. These marks are known as suture lines. Suture lines mark the growth stages of the ammonite shell, and are formed where walls inside the shell meet the side of the shell. Frilly lines like these are only seen on the shells of ammonites. Ammonites such as these are often known as snake-stones because they look a little like a coiled snake. In fact many people have, in the past, even carved snake-like heads onto them.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: no locality data

SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Yorkshire (NE England), Whitby (nr.), Port Mulgrave

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, Pleuroceras hawskerense, collected from the Spinatum Zone, Middle Lias of Early Jurassic, Late Pliensbachian age from North Yorkshire (NE England). Collected by Emma Smith. Shows suture pattern.
NarNarrative: Pleuroceras hawskerense was an ammonite that lived during the early Jurassic, approximately 195 million years ago. This ammonite has a frilly suture line, which can be seen on part of the shell. Suture lines are related to the growth of the ammonite, and form where the inner walls of the shell join the side of the shell. Different species of ammonites occur in different layers of rock and are used to date the rocks in which they are found. Such fossils are known as Zone Fossils.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, North Yorkshire

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, Rasenia involuta, collected from the Cymodoce Zone, Lower Kimmeridgian rocks of Late Jurassic age.
NarNarrative: Rasenia involuta is from the Cymodoce Zone of the Jurassic rocks (about 144 million years ago). Ammonites are varied fossils, and they evolved (changed over time) quickly. For these reasons, they are used to divide the rocks of the Jurassic period up into time sections or zones. Each of these zones is named after an ammonite that is common in that section of Jurassic rock.
LocalSum: no locality data

ColPhysicalDescription: Good specimen showing external ornament and suture pattern.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Dorset (SW England), Burton Cliff, Bridport

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, Phylloceras heterophyllum, collected from the Jet Rock Formation, Upper Lias of Early Jurassic age from Whitby, Yorkshire (NE England). Fine specimen showing suture pattern.
NarNarrative: This ammonite has a very simply shaped shell, compared with other ammonites such as Dactilyoceras and Hildoceras, which have shells that are more coiled. If you look closely, you can see the suture lines that cover the surface of the shell, which look a bit like the frilly patterns in a piece of lace. The suture lines form as the shell of the ammonite grows.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, North Yorkshire (NE England), Whitby (nr.)

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, Oppelia sp., collected from unspecified rocks of Middle Jurassic age.
NarNarrative: Oppelia was an ammonite that was alive at the same time as the dinosaurs, during the Jurassic, and was probably eaten by ichthyosaurs, the large marine reptiles that looked a bit like dolphins. On a part of the shell of this ammonite, traces of the frilly suture lines can be seen. The suture lines are formed where the internal walls of the shell, which are related to the growth of the ammonite, meet the outer shell.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: no locality data

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil nautiloid, Cenoceras sp., collected from the Lias of Early Jurassic age.
NarNarrative: Cenoceras was a nautiloid, a sea creature that is related to the modern Pearly Nautilus that lives in the warm waters of the Pacific Ocean. It would have had tentacles, and swum through the sea looking for small animals to eat. The shell of Cenoceras is similar to the shells of ammonites. The main difference between the shells of ammonites and nautiloids is the suture lines, which are formed where the walls of the inner growth chambers meet the shell. In ammonites, these are usually quite frilly, like a piece of lace. In nautiloids, like this one, they have more of a smooth, curved shape.
ComName_tab: , cenoceras sp., Animalia Invertebrata Mollusca Cephalopoda Nautiloidea
LocalSum: no locality data

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil crustacean (crab), unidentified, collected from the Thames Group, London Clay Formation (?) of Tertiary, Early Eocene, Ypresian age. Collected by J. Goring.
NarNarrative: Crabs are found in shallow, coastal waters in a variety of different environments, especially rocky shorelines. Their tough exoskeleton (external shell) is made out of chitin, a substance similar to finger nails. They are predators and feed mainly on bivalves and gastropods that they break open with their claws. This specimen shows a well-preserved body carapace (shell) with claws and legs.
ComName_tab: Unidentified Crab, , Animalia Invertebrata Arthropoda Crustacea
LocalSum: no locality data

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, Rasenia involuta, collected from the Lower Kimmeridgian rocks of Late Jurassic age from Market Rasen, Lincolnshire (Midland England). Collected by R. Howse.
NarNarrative: Rasenia involuta, an ammonite from Market Rasen, Lincolnshire. This ammonite has been named after one of the places where it is commonly found. Fossils are also sometimes named after people, or given a descriptive name which describes their appearance. This ammonite has been replaced by iron pyrite (fool's gold), with irridescent colours (like a shiny blue butterfly wing), including pink, green and blue.

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, Skolekostephanus skolex, collected from unspecified rocks of Middle Jurassic age from Bridport, Dorset (SW England). Collected by G. Ruppell.
NarNarrative: Ammonites are found in all different sizes. Some are only a few millimetres across, while others are more than a metre wide. Ammonites died out at the same time as the dinosaurs, 65 million years ago. They looked a bit like the modern Nautilus that lives in the Pacific Ocean. Ammonites used a jet propulsion system to help them move around. By squirting a jet of water from their shell, they could move backwards very quickly.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Cephalopoda & Ammonoidea : : : Cephalopoda : Mollusca
LocalSum: UK, England, Dorset (SW England), Bridport

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil echinoid (sea urchin), Conulus albogalerus Leske, collected from the Cortestudinarium Zone = Mucronata Zone, Upper Chalk Formation of Late Cretaceous, Senonian age.
NarNarrative: This sea urchin takes its name from its cone shaped test (skeleton). In life, the test was covered with skin and short bristle like spines that helped the echinoid burrow. The smooth shape shows the sea urchin burrowed in soft seabed sediments. It lived in an open sea environment where the salinity (salt content) of the sea water was normal and fed on food particles found in sediments that it ate. Its mouth is on the flattened lower surface.

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil coral, Lithostrotion sp., collected from the Millstone Grit Group, Great Limestone of Early Carboniferous, Namurian, Pendleian age from Harehope Quarry, Frosterley (nr.), Co Durham (NE England). Collected by A.S. Davison.
NarNarrative: This mass of tube-shaped coral skeletons is part of the colonial coral Lithostrotion (a group of corals living together). A living coral polyp would have occupied a cup shaped hollow at the top of each tube. The polyp looked like a sea anemone with a mouth in the centre of a ring of tentacles that it used to capture small animals as food. Like most corals it lived on the floor of warm shallow seas near the equator.
LocalSum: UK, England, Co. Durham (NE England), Frosterley (nr.)

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Pecten sp., collected from the Red Crag (?) of Tertiary, Early (?) Pleistocene age. Encrusted with barnacles and serpulids.
NarNarrative: The barnacle and worm tube are cemented (glued) onto the large flat scallop shell. The scallop probably died and its two shells separated before the other animals became attached to it. The tubes on the shell were made by a Serpula worm to provide protection for its soft body on the seafloor. Barnacles are a special type of crustacean (related to crabs and lobsters) that can live on the rocks on the sea shore.
SciName: Animalia & Invertebrata & Mollusca & Bivalvia : : : Bivalvia : Mollusca

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bryozoan (sea mat or moss animal), Retepora cellulosa, collected from the Red Crag of Quaternary, Early Pleistocene age from Suffolk (SE England).
NarNarrative: The skeleton of this Bryozoan (moss animal) colony consists of joined tubes that were built by the thousands of microscopic animals (zooids) that lived in it. A close look at the tubes reveals small holes (cysts) where the soft-bodied zooids lived. The zooids fed on tiny single-celled plants that they caught with their tentacles. The colony probably lived in a low energy shallow water environment at depths between 20 and 80m where its food supply was most abundant.
ComName_tab: Sea Mat (or Moss Animal), retepora cellulosa (johnston), Animalia Invertebrata Bryozoa
LocalSum: UK, England, Suffolk (SE England)

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil echinoid (heart urchin), collected from unspecified rocks of Tertiary age. Collected by William K. Loftus. Spatangoid or 'Heart urchin'.
NarNarrative: This heart-shaped fossil sea urchin is a typical burrowing echinoid. It has a smooth shell and streamlined shape which allowed it to burrow through soft seabed sediments for its food. Its burrow also provided protection from predators and prevented it being moved by seafloor currents.

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil ammonite, Harpoceras sp., collected from the Alum Shale of Early Jurassic age from Yorkshire (NE England). Collected by Emma Smith.
NarNarrative: The shell of this ammonite, Harpoceras, has been partly replaced by iron pyrite (fool's gold), which gives the fossil a slightly brassy or metallic appearance. The ammonite, which looks a bit like a ram's horn, has a very distinctive 'v' shaped pattern on its surface. Ammonites get their name from the Egyptian god Amun. Amun was later portrayed by the Greeks as a ram with curling horns.

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil bivalve, Anadara idonea, collected from the St. Marys Formation of Tertiary, Miocene age from St. Marys River, Maryland, USA. Collected by David M. Lumsden.
NarNarrative: The single, thick shell of this fossil bivalve is covered with coarse ribs. Anodara lived in a shallow burrow on a sandy seabed in a shallow water environment. It had leathery tubes (siphons) that it extended up to the seabed surface, which it used to pump water through its body and filter out tiny food particles.

ColPhysicalDescription: Specimen of a fossil fish (shark tooth), Lamna elegans, collected from the Red Crag of Quaternary, Early Pleistocene age from Suffolk (SE England). Collected by Edward Charlesworth (?).
NarNarrative: The elegant shape of this tooth gives the medium sized shark its second (species) name. Its first name (genus) is from Greek and means 'voracious fish'. Living relatives of the fish grow up to 3 metres long and include the mackerel-shark and porbeagle-shark that live in cool oceans and coastal waters. They are predators that feed mainly on shoals of fish such as mackerel and herring. Unusually for shark teeth the edges are not serrated (saw-toothed) for cutting up their prey.
ComName_tab: Shark, lamna & elegans (agassiz), Animalia & Chordata & Vertebrata & Pisces
LocalSum: UK, England, Suffolk (SE England)

ColPhysicalDescription: Part of the upper mandible of a Great Auk; mainly consisting of the premaxilla. The bone is broken off at the proximal end. This bone was discovered in April 1878 in a sea cave at Whitburn Lizards during limestone quarrying operations. A  large number of other bones and bone fragments were discovered in cave earth deposits at this site. It was identified amongst a parcel of bones sent to John Hancock in the same year.
SciName: Pinguinus impennis : Alcidae : Charadriiformes : Aves : Chordata
LocalSum: UK, England, Tyne and Wear (NE England), South Shields, Whitburn Lizards
MulDescription: 'Transcript - "Upper mandible of Grt: Auk from No. 1. Cave Marsden 9th April 1878. Through the kindness of Mr John Daglish I am in possesion of this relic. I discovered the bone in the first package of bones sent. - J. Hancock"
